prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: It was more than possible.

responses.text: It was more than possible. In fact, it was inevitable. For weeks, Mia had studied the flight patterns of the monarch butterflies, charted their migration routes, and camped beneath the trees where they gathered. Her notebook was filled with sketches and data, each page a testament to her determination. Today, as the sun crested the horizon, she rose early, heart thrumming with hope. She followed the winding path through dew-soaked grass, her eyes searching the sky. And then, just as she reached the old sycamore, she saw them—thousands of orange wings shimmering in the golden light. Mia sat quietly, awed by their beauty and resilience. It was a moment she’d dreamed of, proof that with patience and care, even the most fragile wonders could be witnessed. She smiled, grateful to be a part of something so extraordinary.

It was more than possible. It was destiny, or so everyone in the village believed. The old clock tower had been silent for decades, its chimes lost to time. But young Tom, tinkerer at heart, saw potential in the rusted gears and broken springs. Every evening, after finishing his chores, he’d sneak up the narrow staircase carrying his toolbox. Days turned into weeks, and each night he made a little more progress. The townsfolk thought it a fool’s errand, but Tom persisted. One crisp morning, as the village awoke, the clock tower rang out a deep, melodic chime. Windows flew open, laughter echoed in the streets, and Tom grinned from his perch high above. Against all odds, he had brought music back to the heart of the village.

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: It was more than possible.

responses.text: It was more than possible. It was certain, at least to Eleanor as she stood on the edge of the abandoned pier, moonlight glinting off the water. She clutched the faded letter in her hand, the words of her grandfather echoing in her mind: “The truth lies where the river bends.” For years, townsfolk had dismissed tales of hidden treasure, but Eleanor trusted the stories. Tonight, she followed the current’s gentle sway, searching for the ancient oak. When she found it, she dug beneath its roots and unearthed a metal box. Inside, she discovered not gold, but a collection of letters, photographs, and a map. The real treasure was family history, a legacy waiting to be shared. Eleanor smiled, knowing her journey had only just begun.

It was more than possible. It was already happening, though no one noticed at first. The city’s gardens began to bloom out of season, splashes of color emerging where there was only winter gray. Anna, a botanist, was the first to suspect something was amiss when she saw daffodils pushing through snow. As the days passed, vines crept up stone buildings and fruit trees ripened overnight. People marveled at the abundance, but Anna worried. She took samples, wrote papers, and pleaded with the council to investigate. Eventually, the world realized nature was shifting, adapting faster than ever before. Anna’s warnings became guidance, and she helped the city learn to thrive in a new, blooming world.

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: It was more than possible.

responses.text: It was more than possible. It was a promise whispered on the wind, woven through the tall grass behind the old farmhouse. When Alex stumbled upon the peculiar, moss-covered key, curiosity tugged at him. He followed the key’s pull to the forgotten cellar door, hidden beneath creeping ivy. The lock clicked open, and a staircase spiraled down into a chamber bathed in gentle, emerald light. Crystals lined the walls, humming softly, while strange plants bloomed in impossible colors. Alex realized he’d found a secret garden, untouched by time, waiting for someone to tend to it once more. As he stepped into the glow, wonder blossomed in his chest and, for the first time, he felt the world’s quiet magic awaken around him.

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: Wulf said, ‘Was I really the only one who lived?’ ‘It appears so.

responses.text:
Wulf said, ‘Was I really the only one who lived?’

‘It appears so.’

The words echoed through the ash-strewn silence, bouncing off the hollowed trunks and shattered beams that once held laughter. Wulf’s boots crunched glass and bone as he stumbled forward, the weight of survival anchoring him to the spot. He wanted to scream, but the air tasted of smoke and regret.

She—her name lost to the wind—stood by the blackened well, arms folded tightly. ‘The others…’ she started, but her voice broke. ‘There was nothing anyone could do. The fire came too fast, and the river ran dry.’

Wulf closed his eyes. He remembered the night sky blazing orange, the frantic shouts, the press of bodies fleeing into the dark. He remembered, too, the cold terror as he realized no one else had followed him out.

‘Why me?’ he whispered.

She shrugged, her face unreadable. ‘Sometimes the world chooses survivors at random. All that’s left is to decide what you’ll do next.’

Wulf gazed into the ruins. Somewhere, beneath the rubble, the seeds of a new beginning waited. He took a breath, and started to clear the broken stones.

Wulf said, ‘Was I really the only one who lived?’

‘It appears so.’

The words hung heavy in the smoky air. Wulf stared at the scorched horizon where the village had once stood, a bitter ache settling in his chest. The stranger beside him—a gaunt man with soot-stained hands—shifted uneasily, as if wanting to offer comfort but finding none to give.

‘I don’t understand,’ Wulf murmured. ‘I should have been with them. I tried to warn them, but—’

The stranger shook his head. ‘Sometimes fate is cruel and senseless. Survival is not always a reward.’

Wulf knelt and picked up a charred trinket from the ground, the only remnant of his former life. Memories flashed: laughter around the fire, children’s games, the smell of baking bread. All gone.

He felt the weight of solitude press upon him, but beneath it, a stubborn ember of resolve flickered. He could not bring the others back, but he could carry their stories, rebuild what was lost, and ensure the devastation was not the end.

With trembling hands, Wulf stood. ‘Then I’ll be the one to remember.’

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: Wulf said, ‘Was I really the only one who lived?’ ‘It appears so.

responses.text:
Wulf said, ‘Was I really the only one who lived?’

‘It appears so.’

The silence between them stretched, thick with the memory of what had been lost. Wulf’s eyes wandered over the field, the earth still scarred, smoke curling from the last embers of the battle. He could not shake the image of friends and family, laughter turned to screams, warmth to cold ash.

‘Why did I survive?’ he asked, voice trembling. He half-expected no answer, but the figure beside him, cloaked in gray, replied softly.

‘You were meant to witness. To remember. You are the thread that ties the past to whatever comes next.’

Wulf let out a shaky breath. The weight of so many stories pressed on him. He bent, scooped a handful of dirt, and let it fall through his fingers. Each grain was a memory, a promise not to forget.

‘Then I’ll make sure they’re remembered,’ he said. ‘All of them.’

Wulf said, ‘Was I really the only one who lived?’

‘It appears so.’

Wulf’s hands trembled as he wrapped his coat tighter. The valley below lay quiet, shrouded in morning mist, no trace of the bustling life that once filled it. The other survivor, a woman whose name he hadn’t learned, stared at the horizon, her eyes hollow.

‘What do we do now?’ Wulf asked, though he knew she had no answer.

She shook her head. ‘Survive. Rebuild. Or leave it to rot. It’s our choice.’

He glanced at the battered locket in his palm, the last piece of his sister. ‘I can’t leave. Not yet.’

She managed a thin smile. ‘Then we start again, with memories and ruins. And each other, for now.’

Wulf nodded. The dawn broke through the clouds, soft and golden, and for the first time, hope flickered at the edge of despair.

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: Wulf said, ‘Was I really the only one who lived?’ ‘It appears so.

responses.text:
Wulf said, ‘Was I really the only one who lived?’

‘It appears so.’

The wind whistled through broken windowpanes as Wulf stared at the ghostly shells of homes once filled with laughter. Shadows flickered across the ruined street. He touched the jagged scar on his arm—proof of the chaos that had swept through like a storm.

‘But I heard voices last night,’ Wulf insisted, voice trembling. ‘Children, singing.’

His companion, old Marta, shook her head. ‘Echoes,’ she replied, her eyes distant. ‘The town remembers, even if its people are gone.’

Wulf wandered the empty road, unsure whether to trust his senses. He paused at the square, where an oak tree still stood, defiant. As dusk settled, a gentle humming drifted through the air again, unmistakable now. Wulf placed his palm on the tree’s trunk, heart pounding. The song rose—soft, mournful, but alive.

Perhaps, Wulf thought, he was not entirely alone; perhaps memory and hope lingered, singing in the bones of the earth.

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: I spot the shiny foil corner of a sealed condom and pull it out from beneath an avalanche of paper clips and broken pencils.

responses.text:
I spot the shiny foil corner of a sealed condom and pull it out from beneath an avalanche of paper clips and broken pencils. The forgotten drawer in the staff lounge was a time capsule of office detritus, and this accidental discovery brought a smirk to my face. It must've slipped in during the last office party, when everyone was a little too loose with their belongings and the boundaries between personal and professional blurred.

I twirl the packet between my fingers, debating whether to toss it or stash it back into the chaos. Out of nowhere, Linda peers over my shoulder, her eyebrows arched. “Planning a wild lunch break?” she teases, her tone light but her eyes curious. I laugh, more embarrassed than I care to admit, and shake my head. “Just cleaning up,” I reply, tossing the condom into the trash with exaggerated flourish.

Linda grins, grabbing a handful of paper clips. “Let’s leave the treasure hunts for Friday afternoons.”

As we sort through the drawer, I wonder what other stories are buried in the clutter—what else might surface if we dig deep enough.

I spot the shiny foil corner of a sealed condom and pull it out from beneath an avalanche of paper clips and broken pencils. My cheeks flush with embarrassment—this is not the sort of thing you want to find while cleaning out your grandfather’s old desk. I glance over my shoulder, half-expecting him to walk in, even though he’s been gone for years.

Curiosity gets the better of me. I study the expiration date: 2006. My lips curl into a grin. Grandpa always was a bit of a mystery, and now, as I dig deeper through drawers filled with faded photographs and tax receipts, I realize there’s a side of him I never knew. Maybe he was more adventurous than he let on.

I slip the condom into the trash, feeling a strange mixture of amusement and nostalgia. The desk creaks as I open the next drawer. A stack of postcards tied with twine sits inside, each stamped with places I’ve only dreamed of visiting. It seems Grandpa’s secrets are sprinkled everywhere, waiting to be found by someone curious enough to look.

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: Between Bastian’s party and waking up at the first snap of dawn, she was tired, too.

responses.text: Between Bastian’s party and waking up at the first snap of dawn, she was tired, too. The city still glimmered with the memory of laughter and music, its streets empty except for her echoing footsteps. She traced her path home, heels dangling from her hand, dress crumpled at the hem. The world felt heavy and soft, like the last note of a lullaby. At her apartment, sunlight crept through the blinds in golden stripes. Her phone blinked with unread messages, but she ignored them, letting the silence settle. She brewed coffee, the aroma swirling with memories of last night’s revelry. Bastian’s laughter, the clink of glasses, the promise of something new. She closed her eyes, savoring the stillness. In the quiet, she realized fatigue was more than physical; it was the gentle ache of change, the bittersweet end of something beautiful. She smiled, knowing soon enough, she’d be ready for whatever came next.

Between Bastian’s party and waking up at the first snap of dawn, she was tired, too. The night had been a swirl of voices and music, laughter echoing in the corners of her mind. Now, as the pale morning light crept across her bedroom floor, she found herself tangled in sheets, hair mussed, eyes heavy. She stretched, feeling the weight of exhaustion and something else—a residue of magic from the evening before. Bastian’s stories had lingered long after the guests departed, curling around her thoughts. She remembered his promise, whispered between sips of champagne, and wondered if he’d keep it. With a sigh, she padded to the window, drawing back the curtain to greet the world. The city was quiet, dressed in the hush of early hours. She smiled, rubbing her eyes. Maybe tonight she’d rest, but for now, she carried last night’s dreams with her into the dawn.

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: Her thoughts felt slow and heavy.

responses.text: Her thoughts felt slow and heavy. The rain at the window seemed to echo her mood, drops sliding down the glass in languid trails. She sat on the couch, mug of tea cradled in her hands, unsure whether to sip or simply let the warmth seep into her palms. The day had dragged, each minute stretching thin like taffy. She tried to remember what had made her laugh last week, but the memory was fuzzy, like a distant dream. The clock ticked on, indifferent. Outside, the streetlights flickered on, one by one, casting orange halos in the mist. She closed her eyes, drawing a deep breath, and let herself drift. Maybe tomorrow would be lighter, she thought. Maybe the heaviness would lift with the clouds, and sunlight would find her again.

Her thoughts felt slow and heavy. Even as she tried to focus on the sound of her own breathing, a dull ache pressed behind her eyes. The world outside her window had faded into a blur—gray sky, the low hum of distant traffic, the occasional flash of headlights. She reached for her notebook, but her fingers hesitated, hovering above the page. Words used to come easily, tumbling out in bright, eager lines. Now, each one felt like a stone she had to unearth, slow and deliberate. Still, she wrote. Even if her sentences were awkward, even if her ideas tangled and stalled, she wrote. One word at a time, she tried to find her way back to herself.

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: Her thoughts felt slow and heavy.

responses.text: Her thoughts felt slow and heavy. She pushed through the thick fog of her mind, each idea arriving as if it had traveled miles through molasses. The kitchen clock ticked louder than usual, its rhythm reminding her that time moved forward, even if she could not seem to follow. She glanced at the half-written letter on the table. The words blurred together, their meanings slipping through her grasp. With a sigh, she stood and moved to the window, letting the early morning chill prickle her skin. Maybe if she listened closely to the world outside—the distant laughter, the soft rustle of leaves—her thoughts would find the lightness they once had. For now, she simply watched and waited, hoping clarity would return with the dawn.

Her thoughts felt slow and heavy. Each memory surfaced sluggishly, as though she were wading through deep water. She stared at the ceiling, tracing invisible patterns with her eyes, trying to piece together the fragments of her day. The weight of unspoken worries pressed against her chest, but she lacked the energy to untangle them. Outside, a dog barked and a car door slammed, distant sounds that barely registered. She reached for her phone, then set it aside, deciding instead to rest in the quiet. Maybe with time, the heaviness would fade, and her mind would clear. Until then, she let herself drift, surrendering to the slow current of her thoughts.

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: Her thoughts felt slow and heavy.

responses.text: Her thoughts felt slow and heavy. She wandered the corridors of her mind as if each step was taken underwater, memories floating up in bubbles, bursting before she could catch them. The world outside her bedroom flickered with the neon buzz of city life, but inside, time stuck stubbornly to her like wet sand. She pressed her forehead to the cool window, searching the empty street for something—anything—that might jolt her back into herself. A single moth circled the porch light, persistent against the darkness. She watched it, envy blooming in her chest for its simple purpose. For a moment, she let herself believe that, like the moth, she too could find her way toward the light, even if her wings felt too heavy to lift.

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: Wulf said, ‘Was I really the only one who lived?’ ‘It appears so.

responses.text:
Wulf said, ‘Was I really the only one who lived?’

‘It appears so.’

The words echoed in the cavernous hall, bouncing off pillars that had once held banners and laughter. Wulf’s boots crunched glass on the marble floor. He stared out at the rubble, the overturned tables, the tattered flags of his people.

‘How?’ he whispered, half to himself, half to the silent figure beside him. The old man’s eyes, clouded but sharp, watched him closely.

‘You were meant to survive. Sometimes, fate chooses a single thread to tie up the story.’

Wulf clenched his fists, feeling the weight of loss press against his ribs. He had always thought himself ordinary—a soldier among soldiers, a voice in the chorus. Now he was the last note lingering after the symphony faded.

‘What do I do now?’

The old man shrugged, cloak rustling. ‘Live. Remember. Build again, if you wish. Or let the memory rest.’

Wulf stepped forward, out into the dawn. Behind him, the city mourned. Ahead, the world waited, empty, expectant, and new.

Wulf said, ‘Was I really the only one who lived?’

‘It appears so.’

The silence that followed was thick, broken only by the distant crackle of burnt wood settling. Wulf’s hands trembled as he knelt beside the last embers of the campfire, staring into the remains of what used to be their home.

‘Why?’ he managed, his voice barely above a whisper.

The old woman beside him shook her head. ‘Some things we can’t know. The storm was cruel to all but you.’

Wulf traced the scars on his arm, souvenirs from the night chaos tore through the valley. He remembered the screams, the wind, the darkness swallowing everything. Now, only the echo of that night remained, and him—a lone witness to what once was.

He stood, squaring his shoulders. ‘If I am the only one, then I must remember. I’ll carry their stories until I find someone to tell them to.’

The old woman smiled sadly. ‘That is all any of us can do, Wulf. Live, and remember.’

And so, Wulf walked into the uncertain dawn, carrying the weight of memories and hope alike.

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: Wulf said, ‘Was I really the only one who lived?’ ‘It appears so.

responses.text:
Wulf said, ‘Was I really the only one who lived?’

‘It appears so.’

A chill wind swept through the ruins as Wulf stared into the smoldering remains of the village. The silence was unnatural—no laughter, no clatter of carts, just the low moan of the wind through broken rafters. He tried to remember the chaos: the flames, the screams, the shouts of warning that barely rose above the storm. It felt like a fever dream, unreal, until the emptiness pressed in on him.

Old Yara, the healer, leaned heavily on her staff beside him. ‘You mustn’t blame yourself, Wulf. Sometimes the river claims all but one stone.’

He shook his head. ‘But why me?’

Yara’s eyes were sad, knowing. ‘Survival is rarely fair, child. Perhaps there’s purpose in your being spared.’

Wulf looked out across the blackened fields, feeling the loneliness settle in his bones. The world was silent, waiting for his next step. For now, he only knew this: he would have to find a new reason to keep walking.

Wulf said, ‘Was I really the only one who lived?’

‘It appears so.’

The words hung in the air, fragile as morning mist. Wulf staggered to his feet, his body aching with wounds both seen and unseen. Around him, the remnants of the village smoldered, and the scent of smoke twisted in his lungs.

He turned to the figure beside him—a crow, perched solemnly on a charred fence post. It cocked its head, as if it understood the weight of the moment.

‘What now?’ Wulf whispered, voice hoarse.

The crow cawed, flapping its wings once before taking flight. Wulf watched it vanish into the gray sky, a black streak against the dawn.

He took a trembling breath and began to walk. Each step felt like a promise to the ones lost: that he would remember, that he would survive, and that, somehow, he would find meaning in the ashes.

As the sun broke through the clouds, Wulf pressed on, alone, but not defeated.

‘It appears so.’

The voice was not human, though it spoke in a tongue Wulf understood. The shadows coalesced into a figure woven from moonlight and ash, its form shifting with every flicker of the dying campfire. Wulf’s eyes darted to the edge of the clearing, expecting monsters or ghosts, but there was only the wind, and the specter who watched him with ancient, patient eyes.

‘All others have passed beyond the veil,’ it said gently. ‘But you linger, a thread unraveled from the tapestry.’

Wulf shivered. ‘Why me? Was it fate, or chance?’

The specter’s smile was as thin as fog. ‘Sometimes the world needs a witness. Sometimes it needs a seed.’

As dawn broke, the creature faded, leaving Wulf alone beneath the battered sky. He pressed his palm to the earth, feeling the pulse of something new stirring beneath the soil. In the hush, he realized survival was not an ending—it was a beginning. With nothing but memory and hope, Wulf rose, determined to shape the silence into song.

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: Between Bastian’s party and waking up at the first snap of dawn, she was tired, too.

responses.text:
Between Bastian’s party and waking up at the first snap of dawn, she was tired, too. The confetti tangled in her hair was a reminder of how she’d danced without care, letting herself be pulled through song after song despite warnings from her aching feet. 

Now, the world was quiet. Golden light crept across the floorboards, illuminating the empty glasses and half-eaten slices of cake she’d carried home for breakfast. She perched on the edge of her bed, rubbing her eyes. She’d promised herself she would go for a run, start her day fresh, but her body protested. Instead, she wrapped herself in a blanket and watched the city come alive from her window. For a moment, she let herself savor the tiredness—a souvenir from a night well spent and a gentle reminder that sometimes, exhaustion is just another word for living fully.

Between Bastian’s party and waking up at the first snap of dawn, she was tired, too. The echo of laughter lingered in her mind, threaded with fragments of conversation and the sharp taste of champagne. Her dress was still crumpled at the foot of the bed, glitter pressed into the fabric from hours of dancing. She shuffled to the kitchen, bare feet cool against the tiles, and turned on the kettle, breathing in the silence that followed the chaos.

Outside, the city was only beginning to stir. She watched streaks of sun slide across the window, promising a new day. Despite the heaviness in her limbs, she smiled. The party had been a reminder that even after long, quiet weeks, she could still be swept up in something bright and unpredictable. Now, with her mug warming her hands, she decided tiredness was a small price to pay for a night spent living instead of just existing.

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: Is he building ships, too?” Alie asked.

responses.text:
“Is he building ships, too?” Alie asked.

Her grandmother paused her knitting, glancing out the window at the distant figure in the shed. The late afternoon sun painted the sky in streaks of lavender and orange, casting long shadows across the yard.

“Not ships this time, darling. Something smaller, I think.”

Alie pressed her face to the glass, squinting. She remembered the summer Grandpa had built her a toy sailboat, carefully carving the hull and painting the sails with her favorite colors. She wondered what he was making now.

Curiosity pulled her outside. She tiptoed across the grass, the scent of cut clover following her. The shed door was open just a crack. Through the gap, she saw Grandpa hunched over his workbench, surrounded by wood shavings and jars of nails. In his hands, he held a tiny wooden bird, its wings unfinished.

He looked up, smiling. “Come in, Alie. I’m making something for your birthday.”

Alie grinned, her heart skipping. Maybe he wasn’t building ships, but whatever it was, she knew it would carry her imagination just as far.

"Is he building ships, too?" Alie asked.

Her mother glanced up from the tomatoes she was slicing, smiling softly. "Maybe. You know how your uncle is. Always working on something in that old barn."

Alie peered through the kitchen window, watching the flicker of movement beyond the wild rose bushes. It was the same way her father used to work—quietly, with sawdust in his hair and plans rolled up under his arm. She remembered the summer evenings spent launching tiny boats in the creek, their sails catching the breeze until dusk.

Unable to resist, Alie slipped on her shoes and padded across the dewy grass. The barn doors were open, and the smell of cedar and paint filled the air. Inside, her uncle was bent over a worktable, carving a small hull. He looked up, catching her gaze.

“Not ships this time,” he said, smiling. "I'm making a plane. For your adventures."

Alie grinned, already imagining soaring over oceans she’d never seen, her uncle’s creation leading the way.

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: Is he building ships, too?” Alie asked.

responses.text:
“Is he building ships, too?” Alie asked.

Uncle Rowan’s laughter drifted from the garage, mingling with the hum of tools. Alie’s older brother, Finn, nodded, eyes sparkling. “He never stops. Last week it was a galleon. Before that, a schooner.”

Alie tiptoed closer, peering through the half-open door. Uncle Rowan was hunched over a wooden frame, hands stained with sawdust. Blueprints littered the workbench. This ship was smaller, sleeker—a racing sloop, perhaps.

Rowan looked up, catching her gaze. “Do you want to help?” he called.

Alie hesitated, then stepped inside. The garage smelled like cedar and ocean dreams. Rowan handed her a tiny hammer. “Every ship needs a good crew.”

Together, they worked—measuring, sanding, laughing. As the hull took shape, Alie imagined it gliding over waves, sails billowed by salt-kissed wind. She wasn’t just watching ships being built. She was building them, too, and in that moment, adventure felt as close as the scent of wood and the warmth of family.

“Is he building ships, too?” Alie asked.

Her brother Sam grinned, brushing a streak of paint from his cheek. “Not exactly. He says these are for flying, not sailing.”

Alie peered into the old shed where their neighbor, Mr. Calloway, worked. The familiar clutter of wood scraps and nails was there, but instead of hulls and masts, odd wing-like frames leaned against the wall.

Curiosity tugged her closer. She tiptoed to the open door just as Mr. Calloway lifted a delicate model into the sunlight. The wings shimmered silver, catching the breeze. “Paper gliders,” he explained, noticing her awe. “Not ships, but they travel far if you let them.”

Sam handed Alie a freshly folded plane. She launched it into the air, watching it soar high above the garden. Laughter bubbled from her lips. Maybe she’d always loved ships, but today she learned that dreams could fly, too.

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: Is he building ships, too?” Alie asked.

He winked. “Not ships, Alie. I’m inventing a music machine. One that can play the sound of the sea.”

Her eyes widened as he twisted a dial. The machine whirred, and suddenly, the room filled with the echo of distant waves and the creak of ships rocking in the harbor. Alie closed her eyes, imagining herself captain on a voyage to far-off lands.

She grinned. Maybe he wasn’t building ships this time, but he was still sending her on adventures—one melody at a time.

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: I once met a Manx man whose daughter had taken her own life after a year and a day spent in some horrific faerie kingdom so lovely that its beauty

responses.text: I once met a Manx man whose daughter had taken her own life after a year and a day spent in some horrific faerie kingdom so lovely that its beauty haunted her. He told me this one stormy evening in Peel, as rain lashed the harbor. His face was drawn, eyes hollow as he recounted her mesmerizing tales of silver trees, singing brooks, and skies that never darkened. She had returned changed—her laughter too bright, her gaze always distant. She would speak of the faerie court’s endless dances, the feasts of honey and wine, and the kindness of a queen whose smile never quite reached her eyes. The beauty, she said, was oppressive, as though every petal and star demanded her soul in return. She grew restless, unable to sleep, unable to make peace with the grayness of our world. "She said the world here was too small, too dull," the man whispered, tears cutting through the grime on his cheeks. "She missed the music, the light—until she could bear it no more." I never saw him again, but in every sunset, I remember the shimmer of sorrow from that otherworldly place.

I once met a Manx man whose daughter had taken her own life after a year and a day spent in some horrific faerie kingdom so lovely that its beauty shattered her faith in the world. He spoke of it with a hush, as if the breeze might carry his words back to that other realm. She had wandered the gorse-choked hills, vanished at twilight, and returned with eyes that never quite focused on the here and now. She described jeweled rivers, palaces spun from spider silk, and music that unraveled the heart. But the beauty was a trap, he said—an endless, perfect day with no rest, no shadows to hide in. When she came home, the gray stone and salt sea of the island seemed hollow, bereft of meaning. "She could never be content after that," he told me, hands shaking around his mug. "How could she?" The faerie kingdom had stolen his daughter, not with malice, but with a terrible, radiant kindness. And so, she slipped away, seeking a silence more honest than that relentless, golden joy.

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: It was more than possible.

responses.text:
It was more than possible. It was inevitable, at least that’s what Mira told herself as she stood at the edge of the old bridge, wind tugging at her coat. The city’s skyline shimmered in the distance, a promise of new beginnings and forgotten fears. For years, she had watched others take the leap—some faltering, some soaring—but tonight, the possibility of change felt as tangible as the worn wood beneath her boots.

She clutched the small silver key in her palm, its ridges pressing into her skin. The letter from her grandmother, discovered only a week ago, had spoken of a hidden door in the city, one that opened only for those ready to face the truth. Mira’s heart pounded with anticipation as she took her first step forward, letting belief carry her across the bridge and into the unknown, where possibility was not just a chance, but a certainty waiting to be claimed.

It was more than possible. For the first time in years, Sam allowed himself to believe that he might actually win this time. The science fair hall buzzed with anticipation, rows of projects glinting under harsh fluorescent lights. His homemade solar water purifier stood between a volcano demonstration and a robot that could barely wobble.

Sam watched the judges approach, his heart thumping like a drum. He remembered the late nights tinkering in the garage, the setbacks, the moments he almost gave up. But here he was, his invention working perfectly, a small pool of crystal-clear water gleaming in the collection tank.

As the judges leaned in, impressed by the simplicity and effectiveness of his design, Sam smiled. It wasn’t just possible that his dreams could come true—it was within reach, and for once, he was ready to grasp it.

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: It was more than possible.

responses.text: It was more than possible. The symbols etched in the rock matched those in her grandmother’s journal—a language lost for centuries, and yet Lena understood them as if they were whispered in her ear. With trembling hands, she pressed the sun-shaped medallion into the central groove. The stone rumbled, shifting slowly, revealing a narrow passage lit by an otherworldly glow. Lena glanced at her brother, excitement and fear mingling in her eyes. Together, they stepped forward, knowing that this was not just a chance at discovery, but the culmination of a promise made generations ago.

It was more than possible. For years, the idea had flickered in the back of Arjun’s mind, a tiny ember sheltered against the winds of doubt. Tonight, as the city’s lights sparkled below his rooftop perch, that ember blazed into certainty. He checked his parachute one last time, heart pounding louder than the traffic far below. This was it—the night he would leap from the tallest building in town, soaring briefly above the world, proving to himself that fear was only as strong as he let it be. With a deep breath and a laugh that echoed in the cool night air, Arjun stepped into the wind, finally embracing the possibility that had guided him to this moment.

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: It was more than possible.

responses.text: It was more than possible. prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: He emerged with the cloth bag, holding it aloft until his mother nodded to indicate he had gotten the right one.

responses.text:
He emerged with the cloth bag, holding it aloft until his mother nodded to indicate he had gotten the right one. Relief washed over him; the last time, he’d grabbed the flour sack instead and they’d spent half an hour cleaning up the white powder from the tiles. He walked carefully this time, avoiding the squeaky floorboard, and handed the bag over. His mother smiled, her eyes twinkling. “Perfect, Jamie. Now, let’s see what treasure you’ve brought.”

Jamie watched as she opened the bag, revealing the ripe tomatoes they’d picked from the garden earlier that morning. She pressed one gently, checking for softness, then nodded again. “These will make the best sauce.”

He grinned, feeling the weight of responsibility lift. The kitchen filled with the scent of simmering garlic and herbs, and Jamie basked in the warmth of his mother’s approval. For a moment, the world outside faded away, and all that mattered was the quiet magic of cooking together, the promise of dinner, and the simple joy of having chosen the right bag.

He emerged with the cloth bag, holding it aloft until his mother nodded to indicate he had gotten the right one. The sun filtered through the kitchen window, glinting off her spectacles as she motioned him over. He placed the bag on the counter, careful not to disturb the stack of recipe cards she’d meticulously arranged.

She untied the drawstring and peeked inside. A small smile curled at her lips. "Thank you, Sam. These apples look perfect."

Sam beamed. He’d picked them himself from the old tree in the backyard, climbing higher than he ever had before. His hands still tingled from gripping the rough bark. As his mother began peeling and slicing, he watched, breathless, as the fruit transformed into neat, glistening segments.

“Would you like to help with the crumble?” she asked, offering him the bowl. Sam nodded eagerly, plunging his hands into the cool mixture of flour and butter. Together, they worked in quiet harmony, the familiar rhythm of baking weaving their afternoon into something golden and sweet.

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: He emerged with the cloth bag, holding it aloft until his mother nodded to indicate he had gotten the right one.

responses.text:
He emerged with the cloth bag, holding it aloft until his mother nodded to indicate he had gotten the right one. He approached her, heart pounding, feeling the weight of the bag grow heavier in his hands. The early morning market was already bustling, and he tried to block out the shouts and laughter around him.

His mother opened the bag and peeked inside, her eyes scanning the fresh herbs and wild mushrooms. "Excellent, Daniel. These will be perfect for tonight." She patted his shoulder, and he felt a wave of pride. It was his first time picking the ingredients alone, and he had worried he might choose wrong.

As they walked home, Daniel clutched the bag tightly, imagining the stew his mother would make. He glanced at her and saw her smiling, the lines around her eyes softening. In that moment, he realized it wasn’t just about the food; it was about learning, growing, and sharing a simple task that brought them closer together.

He emerged with the cloth bag, holding it aloft until his mother nodded to indicate he had gotten the right one. He grinned, proud of his accomplishment, and hurried back inside. The kitchen was warm with the scent of cinnamon and roasting nuts. His mother took the bag and emptied its contents onto the counter—walnuts, just as she’d asked.

"Thank you, Eli," she said, reaching for a wooden spoon. "Would you like to help me finish the cake?"

Eli nodded enthusiastically. He loved baking days, when his mother let him stir the batter and sneak tastes of frosting. As he cracked the walnuts and watched them tumble into the bowl, he felt a sense of belonging. The world outside seemed far away, and here, in the heart of the kitchen, everything was right. By evening, the house would be filled with the laughter of friends and the sweetness of cake, and Eli would remember this moment—a small victory, a nod, and the warmth of home.

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: He emerged with the cloth bag, holding it aloft until his mother nodded to indicate he had gotten the right one.

responses.text:

They sat by the window, sunlight pooling on the table, and began to piece together a story from the relics. Each object sparked a memory, each memory a story, weaving their family’s history back into the present. By dusk, the kitchen was crowded with laughter and tales long forgotten, and the cloth bag sat empty but for the warmth it had brought back home.

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: Michaela throws an unreadable look in my direction and follows.

responses.text:
Michaela throws an unreadable look in my direction and follows. The hallway is dim, the only light coming in through the cracked windows at the end. I can hear her footsteps behind me, steady and measured. I want to turn around, to ask her what’s going on, but something holds me back. Maybe it’s the way her silence seems to press against my back, urging me forward. 

We reach the door to the old library. I push it open and the hinges groan, echoing down the empty corridor. Dust motes dance in the thin beams of sunlight. Michaela slips past me, her hand trailing along the edge of a bookshelf as if searching for something. She pauses by the far window, finally meeting my gaze. 

“Are you sure you want to do this?” she asks quietly.

I nod, even though I’m not sure at all. Her lips twitch, almost a smile, but her eyes remain shadowed. Together, we step deeper into the library, the door swinging shut behind us with a muted thud.

Michaela throws an unreadable look in my direction and follows. The train platform is unusually quiet for this hour, the only sounds the distant rumble of an approaching train and the soft patter of rain on the metal roof. I clutch the envelope tighter in my hand, feeling the weight of its contents and the unspoken questions hanging between us.

We walk side by side, neither of us speaking, both acutely aware that this moment could change everything. The train screeches to a halt, doors sliding open with a hiss. Michaela hesitates, glancing at me, her expression still impossible to interpret. I step onto the train first, heart pounding. She follows, her presence a mix of comfort and uncertainty.

As the train pulls away, I finally gather the courage to break the silence. "Do you think we’re ready for this?" I ask, voice barely above a whisper.

Michaela looks out the window, raindrops blurring the city lights. "We have to be," she murmurs. "There's no turning back now."

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: Michaela throws an unreadable look in my direction and follows.

responses.text:
Michaela throws an unreadable look in my direction and follows. The late afternoon sun casts long shadows on the cracked pavement as we weave through the back alleys. I can sense her unease, though she says nothing, her footsteps barely audible behind me. I keep glancing over my shoulder, searching for a hint of her thoughts, but her face remains blank, almost determinedly so.

We stop at the faded red door I told her about. I hesitate, feeling the weight of the key in my pocket, and she stands at my shoulder, silent and expectant. The air between us is thick with anticipation and a sliver of fear. I turn the key and push open the door; the scent of old wood and dust rushes out to greet us. Inside, the secrets I promised her await, tucked away in the darkness. She steps in first, her unreadable look softening just a little as she disappears into the shadows, leaving me to wonder what she’s really thinking—and whether we’re ready for what comes next.

Michaela throws an unreadable look in my direction and follows. The night air is crisp, swirling around us as we walk side by side down the deserted street. Her silence unsettles me, but I don’t press her for words. Instead, I focus on the rhythmic echo of our footsteps and the glow of distant streetlights guiding our path.

She stops suddenly, causing me to halt, too. For a moment, we’re both statues in the moonlight, neither willing to break the fragile quiet. Then, softly, she says, "Are you sure this is the right way?"

I nod, though doubt creeps at the edges of my resolve. Michaela’s eyes search mine, but whatever she’s thinking remains locked away. With a small sigh, she gestures for me to lead on, and together we continue into the unknown. The city around us feels vast and mysterious, but her presence beside me gives me courage. Whatever lies ahead, we’ll face it together—even if I can’t quite read what’s in her heart.

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: Michaela throws an unreadable look in my direction and follows.

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: I follow a bunch of Instagram accounts that are just pictures and the occasional close-up video of whales doing whale shit, like drifting or feeding or surfacing or playing.

responses.text:
I follow a bunch of Instagram accounts that are just pictures and the occasional close-up video of whales doing whale shit, like drifting or feeding or surfacing or playing. It started as a joke after a late-night conversation with friends about spirit animals, but now I find myself scrolling through my feed every morning, mesmerized. There’s something hypnotic about watching a blue whale rise, its broad back catching the sun, or a humpback breaching like it invented joy. 

One evening, after a rough day at work, I lingered on a video of a pod of orcas slicing through glassy water. I watched their synchronized movement, their effortless grace. I realized I was breathing slower, my mind quiet. I started saving my favorite posts, creating a little archive. 

Soon enough, I began to dream about whales—moving through endless blue, weightless, unhurried. The more I watched, the more I wanted to know. I started reading about migration paths, whale songs, and the mysteries of the deep. 

The world above water still tugged at me, but somehow, following those whales, I found a kind of peace I’d never known before.

I follow a bunch of Instagram accounts that are just pictures and the occasional close-up video of whales doing whale shit, like drifting or feeding or surfacing or playing. It’s oddly soothing, the way they move—unhurried, heavy, but graceful. There’s one account that posts only at sunrise, the light gold and pink on the water, fin breaking the surface like it’s slicing through silk. 

One morning, I woke up to a notification: a live video. I clicked, expecting the usual, but the camera was shaky, panning wildly. The account holder’s excited voice crackled through—there was a calf, newborn, struggling to the surface for its first breath. I watched, holding my own breath, as the mother nudged it upward. I felt oddly invested, like I was witnessing a secret ritual. 

After that, I paid closer attention. The whales became my little anchor in the chaos of scrolling. I started noticing the way their movements calmed me, the way I’d seek out their videos on stressful days. Maybe, I thought, there’s something to be learned from these creatures: patience, persistence, or just the joy of floating.

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: I follow a bunch of Instagram accounts that are just pictures and the occasional close-up video of whales doing whale shit, like drifting or feeding or surfacing or playing.

responses.text:
I follow a bunch of Instagram accounts that are just pictures and the occasional close-up video of whales doing whale shit, like drifting or feeding or surfacing or playing. I never planned to become a whale aficionado, but there’s a calm in their slow-motion ballet that I can’t get from anywhere else. It’s become my nightly ritual: phone in hand, lights off, I scroll and let the low, guttural sounds of whale calls fill my headphones. Some nights, I imagine I’m the one drifting through the murky blue, weightless and enormous, oblivious to emails and deadlines. 

Last month, I commented on a video of a humpback breaching at sunset, never expecting a reply. Instead, the account owner messaged me. She was a marine biologist stationed off the coast of Alaska. We started chatting about whales, then about everything else. Now, we send each other whale memes and talk about going whale watching together someday. Maybe, I think, the ocean has its own way of connecting people—one whale video at a time.

I follow a bunch of Instagram accounts that are just pictures and the occasional close-up video of whales doing whale shit, like drifting or feeding or surfacing or playing. It sounds like a weird hobby, but it’s the only thing that reliably chills me out after a long day. Sometimes, when I’m lying in bed, I try to imagine the cool darkness of the ocean, the way it must feel to glide through endless blue space. 

One afternoon, I stumbled onto a live feed of a gray whale mother and calf, grazing along the kelp forests. The camera wobbled as the boat rocked, and I watched for nearly an hour, transfixed. It was like meditation, but better. From then on, I started looking for whale videos when I was anxious or couldn’t sleep. I started to recognize individual whales by their scars or markings. They became familiar, like distant friends. Now, every time I open Instagram, it’s not just for distraction—it’s to reconnect with a world that’s slow, wild, and beautifully indifferent to the noise above the surface.

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: She wished that she could love him in the same way that he loved her, except she didn’t know how.

responses.text: She wished that she could love him in the same way that he loved her, except she didn’t know how. Every morning, she watched him pour his coffee with a quiet tenderness, adding just the right amount of sugar, placing her mug beside his with a smile that eased the sharp edges of her doubts. He remembered small things: the way she liked her socks folded, the song she hummed when she was nervous. She felt a gentle ache in her chest, a longing to mirror that affection, to feel it bubble up inside her without effort. But her feelings were more like autumn leaves—beautiful, but brittle, ready to scatter with the slightest breeze. She tried: writing notes, buying flowers, learning his favorite meals. Yet, she sensed a distance, an invisible line she could not cross. One evening, as he traced the constellation of freckles on her arm, she whispered her confession. He smiled, held her a little tighter, and told her that love could take many shapes. Maybe hers was just different, he said, and maybe that was enough.

She wished that she could love him in the same way that he loved her, except she didn’t know how. His love was easy, bright, always present—like the sunlight that crept into her apartment each morning. Hers felt like fog, shifting and uncertain, sometimes thick and close, sometimes far away. She tried to follow his example: holding his hand in public, texting him goodnight, laughing at his jokes. But it always felt just a little bit forced, as if she was playing a part she hadn’t rehearsed. One rainy afternoon, she sat across from him at their favorite café, watching the way he stirred his tea and smiled at her. "I want to love you like you love me," she finally said, her voice trembling. He reached for her hand and squeezed it gently. "You already do," he replied. "Just in your own way." And for the first time, she wondered if maybe, just maybe, her way was enough.

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: She wished that she could love him in the same way that he loved her, except she didn’t know how.

responses.text: She wished that she could love him in the same way that he loved her, except she didn’t know how. He wore his heart on his sleeve, always ready with a kind word or a gentle touch, while her feelings seemed locked behind glass. She admired his patience, his unwavering affection, and wondered if she was broken, or simply different. She read books about love, watched old movies, and tried to mimic what she saw, but nothing ever felt quite right. One evening, after a quiet dinner, she confessed her struggle. He listened, his eyes soft, and took her hand. “You don’t have to love me the way I love you,” he said quietly. “Just love me in the way that you can.” The relief in his words washed over her. She realized that love, in all its forms, was still love. It didn’t need to look the same to be real.

She wished that she could love him in the same way that he loved her, except she didn’t know how. He radiated warmth and certainty, an anchor in the choppy waters of her doubt. She felt unmoored, wanting to give more, to feel more, but unsure of where to begin. He noticed her hesitation but never pressed. Instead, he offered understanding—a gentle squeeze of her shoulder, a reassuring smile. One night, under the pale light of the moon, she admitted her fears. His response surprised her; he simply nodded and said, “Let’s figure it out together.” In that moment, she realized that love wasn’t always a perfect match, but sometimes a journey—one they could walk side by side, learning how to love in their own imperfect, beautiful way.

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: She wished that she could love him in the same way that he loved her, except she didn’t know how.

responses.text: She wished that she could love him in the same way that he loved her, except she didn’t know how. To him, love was grand gestures—a surprise picnic in the park, a handwritten poem left in her coat pocket, a serenade beneath her window on a rainy night. But for her, love was quieter, tangled in thoughts and unspoken glances, hidden in the way she noticed when he needed space or remembered the little things he mentioned in passing. She tried to match his passion, to let her feelings spill out in the ways he seemed to expect, but the words caught in her throat. One evening, she brought him a small jar of fireflies she’d caught at dusk, their glow flickering softly in the dark. He took her hand, smiling, and whispered, “Your love is like their light—small, but wondrous.” In that moment, she realized that love doesn’t have to be loud to be true.

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: I once met a Manx man whose daughter had taken her own life after a year and a day spent in some horrific faerie kingdom so lovely that its beauty

responses.text:
I once met a Manx man whose daughter had taken her own life after a year and a day spent in some horrific faerie kingdom so lovely that its beauty clung to her like a fever. He told me this in a low voice, his hands trembling as he poured me a cup of strong, bitter tea. The faerie kingdom, he said, was not all silvery laughter and golden leaves. It was a place where joy was so sharp it cut deeper than sorrow, and every flower she touched burned her skin with longing for a world she could never truly belong to.

When she returned, he hardly recognized her. Her eyes sparkled with secrets, her smile was too wide, and she wept whenever the wind stirred the lilacs by the cottage door. No matter how he tried, he could never coax from her the story of what she had seen. Only once, before she vanished for good, she whispered, "There are places too beautiful for mortals. They change you forever."

Now the man tends his garden, careful never to let the wildflowers grow too tall, lest they catch the eye of wandering faeries searching for someone new.

I once met a Manx man whose daughter had taken her own life after a year and a day spent in some horrific faerie kingdom so lovely that its beauty gnawed at her soul. He spoke of her as if she were a melody half-remembered: a girl who danced among the gorse and bracken with eyes always fixed on something just out of reach. She disappeared one evening, drawn by a song only she could hear. When she returned, her hair shimmered with starlight and her footsteps barely touched the ground.

The faerie kingdom, he said, was a place where every wish came true—at a price no one could count. She was haunted by visions of crystal rivers and endless feasts, of laughter that echoed long after midnight. Home became gray and silent, the world too small for such extravagant longing. He found her one morning beneath the yew tree, her face serene, a single bluebell in her hand. The note she left behind read, "I have seen too much to stay."

The Manx man walks the moors alone now, warning children to close their eyes if they ever hear music from the hills.

responses.text:
I once met a Manx man whose daughter had taken her own life after a year and a day spent in some horrific faerie kingdom so lovely that its beauty haunted her return. He told me how she wandered the glens, eyes distant, ears straining for music only she could hear. She would not speak of what she’d seen, save for murmurs in her sleep—of emerald forests glowing beneath a violet sky, of feasts where laughter was sharper than knives, of a Queen whose crown shimmered with dew and tears. 

When she came back, everything seemed dull and gray. Food tasted of ash, birdsong became a dirge. The father tried everything—stories, music, even the wise woman from the next village—but nothing could pull her from that otherworldly sorrow. One morning, she vanished, leaving behind only a lock of hair knotted with clover. The Manx man’s eyes brimmed with grief as he finished his story. “Beware the beauty that wounds,” he said, voice trembling. “Some doors, once opened, can never be shut.”

I once met a Manx man whose daughter had taken her own life after a year and a day spent in some horrific faerie kingdom so lovely that its beauty eclipsed all she had ever known. He described how she would sit by the shore, gazing into the mist with a longing he could not reach. She’d returned changed—her laughter too light, her eyes too bright, and her silences stretched on for hours.

The faerie world had lavished her with impossible wonders, but every kindness was barbed, every delight a trap. The memories of golden meadows and jeweled rivers became thorns in her waking life. The Manx man confessed that he’d tried to anchor her with love, with stories, with the warmth of their hearth, but nothing could compare to the haunting perfection she’d left behind. In the end, she slipped away quietly, leaving a note that read, “The world is beautiful, but never so much as the one I lost.”

Now, the man warns travelers to beware the call of faerie music, and never to trust a beauty that asks for nothing in return.

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: Is he building ships, too?” Alie asked.

responses.text:
“Is he building ships, too?” Alie asked.

Her older brother, Finn, didn’t look up from the splinters collecting on the workshop floor. "Not ships," he muttered, "boats. Small ones, for the river."

Alie pressed her nose to the grimy window. Across the yard, their neighbor Mr. Tallow hammered planks in the fading light. His yard was crowded with half-finished hulls and sails folded like secrets.

“But he used to build ships. Real ones, for the sea.”

Finn shrugged. "The sea stopped calling him. Or maybe he stopped listening."

Alie frowned. She remembered stories of storms and cargo, of a world beyond their quiet town. She remembered Mr. Tallow’s laugh, booming like a foghorn when he spoke of distant places.

That night, Alie snuck outside, barefoot in the cold dew. She crept to Mr. Tallow’s fence and watched him fit a tiny mast to a toy boat.

He looked up and smiled. "Would you like to help?" he asked.

Alie nodded. Maybe building boats for the river was enough for now. But she wondered, as the stars blinked above: did the sea miss Mr. Tallow as much as she did?

"Is he building ships, too?" Alie asked.

Her mother glanced up from her knitting, brow furrowed in thought. "Who, dear?"

"Mr. Lanton. I saw him behind the shed yesterday, with all those planks."

A smile tugged at her mother’s lips. "I wouldn’t call them ships. He’s making birdhouses and little boats for the children."

Alie pressed closer to the window, watching as Mr. Lanton hammered away. She imagined the planks rising into the shape of a mighty vessel, sails billowing in the wind.

"When I’m older, I’ll build a real ship," she said softly, mostly to herself. Her mother set her knitting down and ruffled Alie’s hair.

"You can do anything you set your mind to."

Outside, Mr. Lanton waved, and Alie waved back, dreaming of distant oceans and adventures. For now, she would help him build his tiny boats, learning the feel of wood and the patience of hands. One day, she promised herself, she would set out to sea, her own ship dancing over the waves.

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: Is he building ships, too?” Alie asked.

responses.text:
“Is he building ships, too?” Alie asked.

Her father smiled, pausing his careful sanding of the wooden hull on the workbench. “Not ships this time, Alie. He’s making something smaller—canoes, for the lake.”

Alie peered through the open shed door, watching Old Man Harlow fit curved ribs into a frame. The shed smelled of pine and varnish, and the shavings curled like ribbons around his boots.

“Why not ships?” she wondered aloud.

Her father’s hands stilled, and he looked thoughtful. “Sometimes, we make things that fit where we are. The lake is all we need right now.”

Alie watched Harlow work, imagining the canoes gliding across the water, sunlight dancing on the ripples. She thought about the ships her father used to build—grand and sturdy, meant for far-off places. Maybe, she realized, adventure didn’t always have to be far away. Sometimes, it started with a canoe and a quiet afternoon by the lake.

“Is he building ships, too?” Alie asked.

Her cousin Mira grinned, wiping paint from her hands. “Not ships, exactly. He says they’re ‘floating dreams.’”

Alie tiptoed closer to the barn where Uncle Jed worked, his laughter rising with the sawdust. Through the open door, she saw strange shapes—boats, rafts, and something with wings on its sides. Uncle Jed always said the world was too big for just one kind of adventure.

“Do you think he’ll let us help?” Alie whispered. Mira nodded, already headed toward the barn.

Inside, Uncle Jed looked up, his eyes twinkling. “Ah, my new shipwrights! Come give me a hand.”

Alie felt her heart swell. Maybe they weren’t ships for the ocean, but whatever they were, she wanted to help them float. Maybe, if she was lucky, one of those floating dreams would carry her someplace wonderful.

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: Is he building ships, too?” Alie asked.

responses.text:
“Is he building ships, too?” Alie asked.

Grandmother’s rocking chair creaked as she gazed toward the distant cove. “Not ships, child—he’s crafting wings.”

Alie blinked, uncertain. She pictured Uncle Rhys in his cluttered workshop, surrounded by blueprints and the smell of sawdust. She’d seen curved planks, yes, but also feathers and silks, and curious gears that clicked and whirred.

“Wings?” Alie echoed, her voice tinged with awe. “For flying?”

Grandmother’s eyes sparkled. “He always said the sea is only half the world. The sky is the rest.”

That evening, Alie tiptoed to the workshop. Candlelight flickered through the cracks. Inside, Uncle Rhys was fitting canvas to a wooden frame, humming as he worked. He looked up and beckoned her over.

“Ships take you places,” he said softly, “but wings let you see the world from above.”

Alie traced the curve of the wing, heart fluttering. Perhaps she would build ships one day, but tonight, she dreamed of soaring, sky-bound, on the wings her uncle built from hope and wood.

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: I spot the shiny foil corner of a sealed condom and pull it out from beneath an avalanche of paper clips and broken pencils.

responses.text:
I spot the shiny foil corner of a sealed condom and pull it out from beneath an avalanche of paper clips and broken pencils. Instantly, my cheeks flush, glancing around the nearly-empty office to make sure no one saw. The cleaning crew must have jostled my desk drawer again. I’d forgotten it was even in there—a relic from a time when I was optimistic about post-work happy hours turning into something more.

I turn the foil packet over in my hand, the memory of last year’s holiday party flashing through my mind. I’d stashed it away in a fit of hopefulness, but the months had slipped by with nothing but awkward small talk and missed connections. 

A giggle escapes me, half embarrassment, half amusement. I tuck the condom back into the drawer, this time behind a stack of sticky notes. Maybe it’s a sign to try again. Maybe I’ll finally say yes to coffee with Mark from accounting. Or maybe, I think as I close the drawer, it’s simply a reminder that even beneath the clutter of everyday life, little sparks of possibility are waiting to be found.

I spot the shiny foil corner of a sealed condom and pull it out from beneath an avalanche of paper clips and broken pencils. For a moment, I just stare at it, slightly embarrassed, glancing over my shoulder as if someone might catch me in this odd act of excavation. The drawer is a mess, the sort of chaos that accumulates over years of neglect and busy days. I can’t even remember how the condom got there in the first place—maybe from that office safety seminar, or perhaps a gag gift from last year’s secret santa. 

I laugh quietly to myself and set it on the desk beside the jumble of writing utensils. My phone buzzes with a new message: “Ready for lunch?” It’s Sam, my best friend at work, who once joked that my desk was a treasure trove of weirdness. Grinning, I take a photo of the condom surrounded by paper clips and send it to her. “Found today’s prize,” I type. 

Her reply is instant: “Only you.”

I chuckle, feeling a little lighter. It’s just another workday, but sometimes, it’s the small surprises that make it memorable.

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: Her thoughts felt slow and heavy.

responses.text:
Her thoughts felt slow and heavy. Each idea seemed to wade through thick syrup before it reached her consciousness. She pressed her palm to her forehead, hoping the slight pressure might squeeze some clarity out of her foggy mind. The morning sun filtered through the curtains, painting soft gold lines across the comforter, but the warmth did nothing to dispel the weight inside her head. 

Outside, she could hear the distant sound of laughter—the neighbors’ children playing in the yard, their joy a sharp contrast to her lethargy. She wanted to join them, to shake off this feeling like a dog shaking rain from its coat. But even sitting up felt like a monumental task. 

She closed her eyes and focused on her breathing. In, out. In, out. With each breath, the heaviness loosened a little, enough that she could swing her legs over the side of the bed. Today, she decided, she would take things one step at a time. Maybe, by evening, her thoughts would be lighter, nimble enough to chase the laughter spilling in from outside.

Her thoughts felt slow and heavy. She blinked at the ceiling, trying to recall when the world had started moving at half-speed. The clock on her nightstand ticked, each second stretching out, echoing in the stillness of her room. She remembered a time when she would spring out of bed, eager to greet the day; now, even the prospect of standing felt like wading through mud.

As she lay there, images drifted through her mind: the coffee cup she’d left on the kitchen table, the half-finished book on her nightstand, the unopened letter resting by the door. Each one seemed to ask something of her, and she wondered if she had the strength to reply. But then a ray of sunlight broke through the curtains, warming her face. With a slow breath, she gathered her resolve. Maybe the world was moving slowly today, but it was still moving. And so, she would too, even if it was just one small step at a time.

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: Her thoughts felt slow and heavy.

Maybe it was enough just to sit, sip her coffee, and let her mind rest. Outside, a bird sang. She listened, and for a moment, the heaviness eased.

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: Her thoughts felt slow and heavy.

Maybe, just for today, she could allow herself to move with the dust and the golden light. With a soft sigh, she closed her eyes and let her thoughts drift, slow and heavy, but at peace.

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: Is he building ships, too?” Alie asked.

responses.text:
“Is he building ships, too?” Alie asked.

Her question hung in the salty air between them as the sun slid behind the distant cliffs. Marcus didn’t look up from the driftwood he was carving, the shavings collecting in his lap like snow. He paused, turning the small boat in his hands so Alie could see the hull taking shape.

“Not ships,” he replied quietly, “just boats. Enough to reach the islands, maybe. Not enough to cross the great water.”

Alie knelt beside him, watching his hands work. The village had been whispering about her brother, about what he planned to do when the tides shifted. She’d hoped the rumors weren’t true, but the evidence was undeniable. The scent of fresh-cut cedar and tar drifted from the shed each morning; the children gathered pebbles in the cove, pretending to be sailors.

“Do you think he’ll go?” she asked, softer now.

Marcus set the boat down and finally met her gaze. “We all have to choose, Alie. Some of us build ships. Some of us stay and wait.”

She looked out at the darkening waves, wondering which she would be.

"Is he building ships, too?" Alie asked.

The question startled her grandmother, who had been staring out the window, eyes fixed on the docks below. For a moment, she didn’t answer, letting the creak of the old house fill the silence.

“He might be,” Grandmother said at last, folding her hands in her lap. “Your uncle always did have restless hands. After your father left, he started spending his nights at the quay. Wood scraps, plans scribbled on napkins, you know how he is.”

Alie pressed her forehead to the cool glass, watching the flicker of lanterns below. She remembered summers spent chasing her uncle around the shipyard, the taste of salt on the air, his laugh echoing above the hammering.

“Do you think he’ll leave, too?” Alie whispered, afraid of the answer.

Grandmother squeezed her shoulder gently. “Some people are meant for the sea, child. Others for the shore. He’ll decide which soon enough. And so will you.”

Outside, the moonlight danced on the hulls of half-built ships, and Alie wondered where she truly belonged.

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: Is he building ships, too?” Alie asked.

responses.text:

The old man smiled, brushing a curl of sawdust from his weathered apron. "He is," he replied, voice soft as the tide. "But they're not ships for the sea."

Alie blinked, confused. "What do you mean?"

He led her to the back of the workshop, where sunlight filtered through dusty windows. There, on a cluttered table, sat a fleet of delicate wooden ships, their sails stitched from scraps of linen. But beneath them, instead of keels, each ship had sturdy wheels.

"For the land?" Alie guessed, her brow furrowing.

The old man nodded. "He dreams of exploring, not just crossing water but rolling through fields and forests. Ships for journeys no one else imagines."

Alie reached out, tracing a tiny mast. For the first time, she saw her brother's restless spirit mirrored in these small vessels. Adventure, she realized, wasn't just for the ocean. It could find its way across any horizon, if only you built the right kind of ship.

"Is he building ships, too?" Alie asked.

Her brother Tavin stood at the end of the pier, hammering nails into a broad plank. The carcass of a half-finished sloop loomed over him, ribs exposed, smelling of fresh pine and brine.

"Yeah," their father replied, not looking up from his net-mending. "He says he wants to see what’s beyond the cape."

Alie shuffled closer, watching Tavin measure and saw. The last time someone left, they’d returned with wild stories and strange shells, but also a haunted look in their eyes.

"Do you think he’ll really go?" Alie whispered.

Their father sighed, weaving the net tighter. "The sea calls to some louder than others. All we can do is wish him fair winds."

Alie gazed at her brother’s determined back, heart thudding with both worry and pride. She wondered if, one day, she’d feel the call of distant horizons herself.

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: But sadness is an ache I feel I need to continually swallow around, and turns out, sadness also makes it hard to laugh.

responses.text: But sadness is an ache I feel I need to continually swallow around, and turns out, sadness also makes it hard to laugh. I learned this in the quiet winter after my mother left. The house, once filled with the hum of her songs, felt hollow and cold. Every morning, I’d sit at the kitchen table and stare at the mug she used to grip with both hands – chipped and faded, but still hers. My father tried to make jokes, the kind that used to send us into fits of laughter. Now, they fell flat, echoing in the silence. I wanted to laugh, to let the sound bubble up and fill the aching spaces, but it stuck in my throat. Instead, I learned to carry the sadness with me, tucking it away behind tight smiles and polite nods. One evening, my little brother dropped a plate and it shattered. For a moment, he looked terrified, expecting anger or, worse, more silence. But then he giggled – a small, nervous sound. It was contagious. Something broke open in my chest, and I laughed with him. The ache didn’t disappear, but for a moment, it loosened its grip.

But sadness is an ache I feel I need to continually swallow around, and turns out, sadness also makes it hard to laugh. Still, every morning I wake up and try, pushing a smile onto my face before stepping out into the world. The streets are busy, and people walk past with their own burdens, but I feel mine pressing against my ribs, heavy and persistent. At work, my friend Jamie cracks a joke, the kind that used to send me into fits of laughter. Now, I manage a weak chuckle, hoping no one notices how forced it is. Later, I sit alone in the park, watching the sun slip behind the trees, painting the sky with gold and rose. I try to remember the last time I really laughed, the kind that leaves you breathless and light. I can’t. But as a dog chases its tail nearby, something loosens. It’s small — just a smile, barely there, but it feels like a start. Maybe tomorrow, it will be easier. Maybe the ache will fade, just a little, and laughter will come back to me.

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: But sadness is an ache I feel I need to continually swallow around, and turns out, sadness also makes it hard to laugh.

Still, I keep searching for it, holding onto the hope that one day, when the rain stops, I’ll open the window wide and let laughter in again. Until then, I let the sadness sit with me, a companion I neither welcome nor shun, simply acknowledge as part of the weather inside my heart.

But sadness is an ache I feel I need to continually swallow around, and turns out, sadness also makes it hard to laugh. My friends would nudge me, trying to draw me out, but my laughter would stick in my chest, caught behind the ache. Each evening, as I walked home alone, I wondered if the sadness would ever lift or if it had simply become a part of me, stitched into every moment. One night, a stray cat brushed against my leg, purring loudly despite the chill in the air. I smiled, genuinely, for the first time in weeks. Maybe, I thought, laughter would return in small ways—a purr, a shared smile, a moment of warmth in the cold.

It’s become a ritual: every night before sleep, I scroll through these videos, letting the low, echoing whale songs and silent underwater footage wash over me. Sometimes I imagine I’m there, floating in cold water with nothing but endless blue beneath. Once, in a comment, someone wrote, “Whales don’t know about us.” That stuck with me for days. 

Last week, I posted a short clip of my own—just a loop of a whale’s eye blinking, filmed from an aquarium visit years ago. The likes trickled in, mostly from fellow whale-watchers, and for a moment, I felt part of something vast and quiet: a community adrift, all of us watching these gentle giants, longing for the deep.

I imagine what it’s like to be that big, that old, to have no deadlines or notifications, just the rhythm of tides and the occasional krill buffet. 

One day, I commented “#whalemood” on a particularly serene video. The account replied with a whale emoji. I smiled. Maybe that’s enough—little moments of connection, a reminder that there’s still wonder in the world, somewhere deep and blue and mostly undisturbed.

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: I follow a bunch of Instagram accounts that are just pictures and the occasional close-up video of whales doing whale shit, like drifting or feeding or surfacing or playing.

responses.text:
I follow a bunch of Instagram accounts that are just pictures and the occasional close-up video of whales doing whale shit, like drifting or feeding or surfacing or playing. It started as a way to calm down before bed, my mind soothed by endless loops of blue water and slow, gentle giants. But lately, I’ve begun to notice something strange. Every time I see a new video, I feel a tug—a weird, watery ache in my chest, and when I close my eyes, I can almost feel the cold pressure of the ocean around me. 

Last night, I dreamed I was underwater, gliding through shafts of sunlight with a pod of orcas. I could feel the slick slide of water over skin that wasn’t mine. When I woke, I found a small, salt-crusted shell in my bed. I don’t live anywhere near the sea. 

The next day, a new post appeared: a whale breaching, silhouetted against a stormy sky. In the comments, someone had written, “You’ll be home soon.” My heart pounded. I can’t look away. With every post, I feel the current growing stronger, pulling me toward something ancient, deep, and waiting.

I follow a bunch of Instagram accounts that are just pictures and the occasional close-up video of whales doing whale shit, like drifting or feeding or surfacing or playing. It’s oddly mesmerizing, like watching a screensaver come to life, but with the weight of something ancient and unknowable. Sometimes I’ll find myself scrolling through dozens of posts late at night, letting the slow-motion breaches and underwater songs lull me into a kind of trance.

One evening, while watching a video of a humpback circling a cloud of krill, I noticed something in the background: a flash of something metallic, just for a second. I rewound the clip again and again, but it vanished each time. The next day, a different account posted a video from the exact same spot on the same day—but now, the water was empty, as if nothing had ever been there. 

I started to look for clues in every post. Sometimes, I think the whales are trying to tell us something. Or maybe it’s just my imagination, conjuring mysteries out of salt water and sonar songs. But I keep scrolling, drawn deeper into their world, waiting for the next secret to surface.
