prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: I once met a Manx man whose daughter had taken her own life after a year and a day spent in some horrific faerie kingdom so lovely that its beauty

responses.text:
I once met a Manx man whose daughter had taken her own life after a year and a day spent in some horrific faerie kingdom so lovely that its beauty haunted her waking thoughts. He told me this in a voice that trembled like the waves along Douglas Bay, eyes fixed not on me but somewhere far beyond. 

"She came back with flowers braided in her hair," he said. "No mortal bloom, these petals bled blue and gold light. She never spoke of what she'd seen, but her laughter faded. Some nights, she’d stand at the window, whispering to the darkness, as if calling to friends invisible."

He showed me a locket she’d left behind—a curiously cold thing, inlaid with symbols I didn't recognize. 

"I buried it at the crossroads, as old wisdom says," he murmured. "But I think she’s still listening to music we’ll never hear. That faerie beauty—it's a hunger, not a gift."

When I left him, the hills seemed sharper, the wind colder, as though the world itself was somehow thinner, and I wondered whether the faerie kingdom was truly gone—or if it was just waiting for another lost soul to cross its threshold.

I once met a Manx man whose daughter had taken her own life after a year and a day spent in some horrific faerie kingdom so lovely that its beauty followed her back like a curse. He spoke of her as if she were only just beyond reach, her laughter still echoing in the old stone cottage where he lived alone.

"She told me," he said, "that the colors in that world sang to her, and the rivers flowed with memories. Every meal tasted like dreams, every shadow shimmered. But it was never safe, not really. Beauty can be a trap."

He showed me a sketch she’d drawn—a forest of impossible gold trees, and a sky so blue it hurt to look at. "After she returned, nothing here was enough. The sea was dull, the hills flat. She said the world felt paper-thin."

The man spoke with a gentle grief, warning me to beware the lovely places, for their wonder could make you ache for what you cannot have. When I left, I could almost hear her voice in the wind, singing of a kingdom no mortal should ever see twice.

I once met a Manx man whose daughter had taken her own life after a year and a day spent in some horrific faerie kingdom so lovely that its beauty left her adrift between worlds. When I left, the mist tangled around my ankles, and for a heartbeat, I smelled impossible flowers. I have never returned to that place, but sometimes, in dreams, I hear the Manx girl’s song echoing from across the sea.

The clock ticked on, marking the passing time she couldn’t seem to use. Finally, with a sigh, she dropped the pencil and stood up, stretching her arms. Maybe a walk would help, she reasoned. Outside, the air was crisp and cool, and as she walked beneath the swaying trees, she felt the weight inside her begin to lift, just a little. With each step, her thoughts grew lighter, until they moved freely once again.

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: She wished that she could love him in the same way that he loved her, except she didn’t know how.

responses.text:
She wished that she could love him in the same way that he loved her, except she didn’t know how. His affection was effortless, a warm sunrise that greeted her every morning, while she always fumbled for the words, the gestures, the right way to fold her feelings into something recognizable. He would leave little notes on her pillow, cook her favorite meals, and listen patiently to her stories. She tried to reciprocate, but her love felt clumsy, her gestures uncertain.

One rainy afternoon, she sat by the window, watching raindrops trace crooked paths down the glass. He joined her quietly, slipping his hand into hers. "You don’t have to love me like I love you," he whispered. "Just love me in your own way."

She realized then that love didn’t need to look the same on both sides. It could be quiet, hesitant, even awkward. So she squeezed his hand, letting her silence speak. Maybe her love was a gentle rain instead of a sunrise—softer, but nourishing all the same.

She wished that she could love him in the same way that he loved her, except she didn’t know how. Every day, she watched him pour devotion into the smallest things—a cup of coffee placed at her side, a gentle squeeze of her shoulder, a smile that lingered after a shared joke. She admired his openness, the way he seemed to give without hesitation.

But inside her, love was a locked room with windows painted shut. She cared for him, deeply, but when she tried to show it, the words tangled on her tongue. She baked him his favorite pie but forgot to say she’d made it just for him. She bought him books she thought he’d like, but never wrote a note inside.

One evening, as they sat together in the hush of twilight, he turned to her. "I know you love me," he said softly. "You do it your way, and it’s enough."

Relief flooded her. She squeezed his hand, and in that quiet moment, she realized love could look different and still be real.

responses.text:
I follow a bunch of Instagram accounts that are just pictures and the occasional close-up video of whales doing whale shit, like drifting or feeding or surfacing or playing. It started as a joke; my roommate sent me a video of a humpback rolling in the kelp, and I laughed, but then I watched it again and again. There was something soothing about the slow, ponderous way the whale moved, how it seemed to exist outside of time. Soon, my explore page was all whales—all blues and grays, misty plumes of breath, the echo of deep water.

One night, after a particularly long day, I scrolled through my feed in the dark, watching a right whale lunge through a cloud of krill. I felt the tension in my chest loosen. My problems—deadlines, rent, the weird ache of loneliness—felt small next to the vastness of the ocean. I started dreaming about whales: silent, serene, immense. In those dreams, I swam alongside them, weightless and unhurried. And every morning, I’d wake up and check my phone, hoping for another glimpse, another slow-motion breach, another reminder that somewhere, whales were doing whale things, and the world kept turning.

I follow a bunch of Instagram accounts that are just pictures and the occasional close-up video of whales doing whale shit, like drifting or feeding or surfacing or playing. I don’t know when the obsession started, but now my feed is all flukes and breaches, barnacled backs gliding through blue water. Each post feels like a postcard from a parallel universe, one where time moves slow and gravity is just a suggestion.

One lazy Sunday, as I scrolled through another endless loop of a gray whale rolling in the surf, something strange happened. The phone buzzed, and for a moment, the room seemed to ripple. The air thickened, heavy with brine. I blinked, and suddenly I was there, floating in cold saltwater, watching a pod of orcas pass beneath me. My heart hammered, but they didn’t notice me. I was invisible, just another driftwood log in their world. When I surfaced, gasping, I was back in my room, the video paused, my hands trembling. Since then, I watch every new post a little more carefully, just in case I slip through again.

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: I follow a bunch of Instagram accounts that are just pictures and the occasional close-up video of whales doing whale shit, like drifting or feeding or surfacing or playing.

responses.text:
I follow a bunch of Instagram accounts that are just pictures and the occasional close-up video of whales doing whale shit, like drifting or feeding or surfacing or playing. There’s something comforting about it. Sometimes, late at night, I scroll through my feed and watch a blue whale slowly rise to the surface, its massive body catching the sunlight, barnacles clinging to its skin. I imagine myself there, drifting alongside it, feeling the cool water and the deep quiet of the sea.

One day, I commented on a video—a beluga spinning in circles, blowing perfect rings—and someone replied. They said they’d seen whales like that in person, off the coast of Vancouver. We started chatting, swapping favorite accounts and sharing whale facts. Soon, we were messaging daily, sending each other new clips: a calf breaching, a pod of orcas swimming in formation. I realized I wasn’t just following whales anymore—I was following a thread of connection, something vast and slow and kind, threading through the digital deep.

I follow a bunch of Instagram accounts that are just pictures and the occasional close-up video of whales doing whale shit, like drifting or feeding or surfacing or playing. It’s oddly grounding. When the world feels too fast, too loud, I swipe through my feed and lose myself in the slow, deliberate movements of these giant creatures.

Last week, I stumbled on a live stream—a sperm whale idling near the surface, sun dappling its scarred back. I watched for almost an hour, hypnotized. The comments section was full of strangers, sharing whale puns and ocean facts. For a moment, it felt like we were all floating together, suspended in that blue silence. Afterward, I bookmarked the stream. Now, whenever I need to breathe, I go back and watch the replay, letting the rhythm of whale life wash over me, reminding me that not everything has to move at breakneck speed.

One night, after a particularly stressful day, I was scrolling through my feed when I saw a new live video: a sperm whale calf learning to dive. In the quiet of my room, the blue light flickering on my face, I felt connected—to the whales, to the strangers watching with me, and to the vast, mysterious ocean that keeps rolling, whether I’m there or not.

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: The lower offices were sufficiently warren-like that she could sneak upstairs without being observed.

responses.text:
The lower offices were sufficiently warren-like that she could sneak upstairs without being observed. The maze of cubicles, scattered filing cabinets, and half-lit alcoves provided ample cover as she moved from shadow to shadow. Her heart thumped in her chest, each beat echoing louder than the last, but nobody seemed to notice her. 

She paused at the foot of the main staircase, listening for the sound of footsteps. The only noise was the distant hum of an old printer and the drone of voices far down the corridor. Gathering her courage, she slipped up the stairs, careful to avoid the creaky third step. 

On the landing, the air felt cooler, tinged with something metallic. She glanced down at the piece of paper clenched in her fist—the evidence she needed was just behind the frosted glass door at the end of the hall. With a deep breath, she pressed forward, determined to uncover the truth, no matter what secrets the upper offices held.

The lower offices were sufficiently warren-like that she could sneak upstairs without being observed. She moved quietly, hugging the walls, her footsteps muffled by the threadbare carpet. The whir of photocopiers and murmur of distracted conversations masked any sound she might make. She knew precisely when the night cleaning crew passed through, and she timed her ascent accordingly.

Once upstairs, the ambiance changed. The upper floor was silent, bathed in the soft glow of emergency lights. She navigated the hallway toward the records room, her pulse quickening. If she found the file she was looking for, she’d finally have proof. 

She paused outside the heavy wooden door, listening for any sign of movement from within. Satisfied she was alone, she fished the stolen keycard from her pocket and slid it through the reader. The lock clicked open. She slipped inside, determined to uncover the truth that had been buried for far too long.

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: Despite my toxic marriage, I was privileged.

responses.text:
Despite my toxic marriage, I was privileged. My home was spacious, sunlight flooding the kitchen each morning as I brewed coffee and rehearsed the day’s small battles. My friends said I was lucky: I had security, designer clothes, vacations in Tuscany. But I learned that comfort can be a gilded cage. My spouse’s words cut sharper than winter wind, finding faults in the way I dressed, laughed, even breathed. Yet, every evening, I ate with fine cutlery under a chandelier. 

Sometimes, I’d linger on the balcony, watching neighbors walk their dogs or children shriek with laughter in the park. I envied their joy, their freedom. My privilege let me hide my pain behind expensive sunglasses and practiced smiles. But one morning, watching the sun rise over the city, I decided I deserved more than appearances. I packed a single bag, left a note, and closed the door on my privilege—and my prison. For the first time, my heart felt light, untethered. The world outside was uncertain, but it belonged to me.

Despite my toxic marriage, I was privileged. I knew it every time I looked at the bank statement, or when I lay on the Egyptian cotton sheets, or when I glanced at the polished marble countertops. But privilege is a strange thing—it can hide the cracks in the walls, the icy silence at breakfast, the bruises that aren’t on the skin. 

My friends envied my lifestyle, but none knew that my laughter was a mask, that I measured my words to avoid another argument. I told myself that this was the price of comfort, that I could endure anything if I had enough. But late at night, lying awake, I wondered if freedom might be worth more than a walk-in closet. 

One day, I found a note tucked into my book—just a scribbled reminder from myself: "You deserve happiness, not just comfort." That was the day I called my sister and, trembling, asked for help. Privilege had given me a cushion, but courage gave me a future.

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: Despite my toxic marriage, I was privileged.

responses.text:
Despite my toxic marriage, I was privileged. I knew it every time I glanced at the shelves lined with books, the pantry stocked with imported teas, the closet overflowing with tailored coats. My partner’s voice, sharp and dismissive, tried to convince me I was worthless, but the world insisted otherwise. I had choices, resources—an escape hatch that so many others lacked.

One rainy afternoon, as I listened to the storm rattle the windows, I remembered the scholarship letter tucked in my drawer. My privilege didn’t erase my pain, but it offered me a path. I packed a suitcase, heart pounding, and left while he was at work. In the taxi, I watched the city blur by, guilt and relief twisting together. I was leaving behind a life others might envy, but I was finally choosing myself. Privilege had not protected me from suffering, but it gave me a chance to start over—something I promised never to take for granted.

Despite my toxic marriage, I was privileged. I had a career that allowed me to travel, friends who checked in often, and a family who loved me, even if they didn’t fully understand my situation. My husband’s words could wound, and his anger could chill a room, but I always had a safe place to go—a spare key to my sister’s apartment, a network of colleagues who encouraged me to speak up.

One Friday evening, after another argument left me feeling invisible, I sat at my desk and composed an email to my boss: I needed a week off, for personal reasons. The next morning, suitcase in hand, I walked out the door. I knew I was fortunate—many people in my situation had nowhere to turn. As the train pulled away from the station, I allowed myself to hope, for the first time in years, that I could build a better life.

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: Despite my toxic marriage, I was privileged.

responses.text:
Despite my toxic marriage, I was privileged. I could afford therapy, even if I lied about why I was going. My job let me work from home, so I could hide the tears and bruises in privacy. I had a passport full of stamps and a bank account with my own name on it—resources that glimmered like hidden keys in a locked room.

On our tenth anniversary, I sat across from him in a candlelit restaurant, his smile brittle, his hand pressed too tightly on mine. I thought of my friend Mara, who once confessed she had nowhere to go. I realized then that privilege isn’t freedom, but it can be the means to claim it. That night, I booked a flight. No hesitation. I packed my bags before dawn and left a note—no explanations, no apologies.

I landed in Lisbon with nothing but a suitcase and relief. My privilege hadn’t protected me from pain, but it had given me wings. And as I wandered the cobblestone streets, I promised myself I’d never let gratitude become guilt. I would build a life on honesty, not pretense, and that would be my greatest privilege of all.

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: Her thoughts felt slow and heavy.

responses.text: Her thoughts felt slow and heavy. It was as if her mind was wading through syrup, each idea tugging behind it a long, sticky tail of doubt. The rain outside mirrored her mood, drumming softly against the windowpane, blurring the world beyond. She sat at her desk, pencil poised above the untouched notebook, but the words refused to come. Instead, she gazed at the drops racing each other down the glass, letting her mind drift. Memories surfaced—her mother’s gentle voice, the laughter of her childhood friends, a summer day spent by the river. Those moments seemed brighter, lighter, unencumbered by the weight she felt now. Taking a deep breath, she closed her eyes and tried to focus on the warmth of those recollections. When she opened them again, the page remained blank, but something inside her felt a fraction lighter, as if the memories had cleared just enough space for the first word to appear. The evening sun cast long shadows across her living room, and she felt them stretch inside her, too. She tried to remember what had made her so tired, but nothing in particular came to mind—just a general sense of weariness that had settled over her like a blanket. She got up, shuffled to the kitchen, and made herself a cup of tea. The warmth of the mug in her hands was grounding, and she focused on its simple comfort. Slowly, the heaviness began to lift, replaced by the gentle awareness of the present moment. She realized she didn’t need to solve everything tonight. Sometimes, it was enough just to be, to breathe, and to let the slow minutes pass. Tomorrow, she promised herself, would be lighter.

Outside, the city was slowly awakening, just as she was. She watched the sun climb above the rooftops, letting herself feel grateful for memories made. Perhaps she would nap later, she decided, but for now, she would simply be—tired, content, and quietly happy that some nights, and some mornings, were worth remembering.

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: Oh, I’m great.

responses.text: Oh, I’m great. That’s what I told everyone who asked, anyway. The truth was a little more tangled, knotted up somewhere behind my easy smile and casual wave. Each morning, I’d walk by Mrs. Patel’s bakery, inhale the sweet scent of cardamom and sugar, and remember how, not so long ago, I’d sit on the curb with my brother, sharing a pastry and laughter. Now, I kept my hands jammed in my pockets, my phone filled with unread messages, and my stories to myself. But today, as I passed by, Mrs. Patel waved me in. She handed me a warm bun and asked, “How are you, really?” I hesitated, then let out a sigh, feeling the weight of my answer. “I’m… figuring it out,” I said, surprised at my own honesty. She smiled, patting my hand. “That’s a good place to start.” And just like that, I felt a little lighter, the morning air just a bit sweeter than before.

Oh, I’m great. Or at least, that’s what I want everyone to believe. The truth is, life has a way of tossing surprises like confetti—some shiny, some sharp. This morning, I woke up to the sound of rain tapping at the window, a gentle reminder that change is always just outside. I brewed my coffee, checked my phone, scrolled past the usual parade of perfect faces and filtered lives. At work, my colleague asked how I was, and my answer came out smooth and practiced. But later, when I caught my reflection in the elevator, I paused. The person looking back seemed braver than I felt. Maybe, just maybe, saying I’m great wasn’t a lie after all. Maybe it was a promise to myself—a seed of hope that, with enough sunlight and a little patience, might one day bloom into truth.

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: Oh, I’m great.

I opened the door and the cat padded inside, purring softly. As I stroked its fur, the heaviness in my chest eased. Maybe I wasn’t as alone as I thought. Maybe, just maybe, things would be okay.

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: She wished that she could love him in the same way that he loved her, except she didn’t know how.

responses.text: She wished that she could love him in the same way that he loved her, except she didn’t know how. Every day, he brought her small gifts: a daisy tucked behind her ear, a mug of cocoa just the way she liked it, a note hidden in the pocket of her coat. She smiled and thanked him, but her heart stayed quiet. She wondered if there was something wrong with her, if perhaps she was missing a part that let people feel as deeply as he did. He never seemed to notice her hesitance, always bright and hopeful, believing that she would one day return his devotion. Late at night, she lay awake, tracing the patterns of moonlight on her ceiling, searching her heart for a spark. She tried to mirror his gestures, to say the words he said, but they tasted foreign on her tongue. In the end, she realized that love couldn’t be forced. Maybe, she thought, the most honest thing she could give him was her truth. So one morning, she sat beside him, took his hand, and told him gently, “I care for you deeply, but I don’t know how to love you the way you love me.”

She wished that she could love him in the same way that he loved her, except she didn’t know how. It wasn’t for lack of trying. She watched the way he looked at her—eyes warm, voice gentle—and tried to reflect that same softness. But when she reached inside herself, searching for the wellspring of affection he seemed to draw from with ease, all she found was a gentle trickle. She worried he’d notice, that her love would never measure up to his. Yet, he never complained. He simply held her hand, listened to her worries, and celebrated her joys, as if her mere presence was enough. She read books on love, asked friends for advice, and wrote lists of the things she appreciated about him. Still, her feelings didn’t transform overnight. One evening, under the amber glow of streetlights, she confessed her struggle. He smiled, squeezed her hand, and told her love doesn’t always look the same. Maybe, he said, what she offered was enough. In that moment, she realized that learning to love was a journey, not a destination, and that perhaps she was already loving him in her own quiet way.

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: Despite my toxic marriage, I was privileged.

responses.text:
Despite my toxic marriage, I was privileged. I had a career I loved, friends who made me laugh until I cried, and a cozy apartment overlooking the city skyline. Yet, each night I returned to the home I shared with Daniel, where silence hung heavier than words. Our smiles for the world were carefully curated, but inside, resentment simmered beneath the surface. 

One evening, after another argument that left me feeling hollow, I sat on the balcony and watched the city lights flicker. I realized I had opportunities many would envy: enough savings to start over, a passport full of stamps, and a support system ready to catch me if I fell. With trembling hands, I called my best friend. "I can’t do this anymore," I whispered. 

She arrived within minutes, suitcase in hand and hope in her eyes. That night, as I packed my bags, I understood that privilege didn’t erase pain—but it gave me the power to choose my future. I stepped into the night, heart pounding with fear and possibility, determined to build a life where love, not fear, would write the next chapter.

Despite my toxic marriage, I was privileged. My job paid well, I had access to therapy, and my family never hesitated to offer support. Still, the nights were long, and the mornings were heavy. My husband, Alex, had a way of twisting my words, making me question my own reality. But I clung to the privileges I had, knowing so many women had far less.

One evening, after a particularly cruel argument, I found myself scrolling through online forums, reading stories of women who had left. Their courage became a lifeline. I began stashing away money, scheduling therapy sessions during my lunch breaks, and reconnecting with my sister, who promised her couch was always open.

The day I left was quiet. I packed a single suitcase and left a note on the kitchen table. As the taxi pulled away, I glanced back only once. My privilege hadn’t shielded me from pain, but it gave me the resources to escape. I started over, piece by piece, using every resource I had to build a life rooted in kindness and truth.

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: Despite my toxic marriage, I was privileged.

I often reflect on that time—how privilege didn’t protect me from pain, but it offered me a way out. Now, as I sip coffee in my own kitchen, sunlight streaming in, I am grateful not only for what I have, but for the strength to use it when it mattered most.

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: If we’re not in the same room, then I’m usually working on his book.

responses.text:
If we’re not in the same room, then I’m usually working on his book. That’s been our routine for the last three months—he writes his chapters in longhand at the kitchen table, then leaves them for me to decipher and type up. Sometimes, while he’s out for a walk or running errands, I sit at my desk by the window, the pages spread out before me. I try to imagine what he was thinking as he scribbled each note in the margin, or why he crossed out entire paragraphs only to rewrite them with subtle changes. 

I like these hours alone with his words. It’s a different kind of closeness, like I’m holding a part of him in my hands even when he’s not there. When he returns, he always asks, “Did you fix my mistakes?” and I always say, “Only the ones that needed fixing.” Then we laugh, and he pours us tea, and we talk about what the next chapter should be. It’s not just his book anymore, I think. It’s ours, stitched together by all the time we share—even when we’re apart.

If we’re not in the same room, then I’m usually working on his book. That’s how we’ve managed to keep the peace—he needs his space to think, and I need something to keep my hands busy. His words are a puzzle I never quite solve, his handwriting looping and slanting across the page, sentences half-finished, ideas dangling. The manuscript grows with every quiet hour, each chapter a testament to our shared solitude.

Some days I wonder if he writes for me, or if I edit for him, or if we’re both just circling each other in the silence, trying to say something neither of us can speak aloud. The book is a bridge, a way to meet in the middle, even when we’re alone. When I hand him the typed pages, he scans them, nodding, sometimes smiling. "You understand," he says, and I realize it’s true. Maybe we’re not in the same room, but through these pages, we’re never really apart.

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: Her thoughts felt slow and heavy.

responses.text:
Her thoughts felt slow and heavy. It was as if she were wading through thick syrup, every idea dragging at her with a stubborn weight. The morning sun struggled through the curtains, drawing soft stripes on the faded quilt. She stared at them, tracing the patterns with her eyes, hoping for clarity. 

Yesterday, the world had seemed so sharp, so urgent. Now, every memory jostled in her mind, blurring at the edges. She remembered the phone call—the news, the way her heart had thudded in her chest. The words had landed like stones, and now they sat inside her, unmoving.

A kettle whistled in the kitchen, distant and faint. She forced herself to sit up, the effort monumental. With each movement, she tried to shake off the heaviness, but it clung to her. Today, she would let herself move slowly. She would make tea, stare out the window, and let the world pass gently by, until her mind could float again.

Her thoughts felt slow and heavy. Each idea seemed to sink before she could grasp it, like pebbles vanishing beneath a murky pond. The rain drummed steadily against the window, adding to the muffled hush in her small apartment. She rubbed her temples, willing herself to focus, but the fog refused to lift.

She glanced at the clock; somehow, hours had slipped by with nothing to show for them. The unfinished letter on her desk stared up accusingly. She knew she should write, should reach out, but the words wouldn't come. Instead, she wrapped herself in a blanket and listened to the rain, letting the weight of her thoughts anchor her to the moment.

Maybe, she told herself, slow days had their own kind of meaning. Maybe some answers only surfaced when given time. With a deep breath, she surrendered to the stillness, trusting that when her mind was ready, it would move lightly once more.

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: The lower offices were sufficiently warren-like that she could sneak upstairs without being observed.

responses.text:
The lower offices were sufficiently warren-like that she could sneak upstairs without being observed. The labyrinth of cubicles, storage rooms, and half-finished renovations created a perfect cover. She moved quietly, her footsteps muffled by the old carpet, heart pounding in her chest. The fluorescent lights flickered overhead, casting odd shadows that made her flinch every few steps.

At the far end of the hall, she slipped past a half-open supply closet and found the narrow staircase. This was the only route that hadn’t been blocked off for repairs. Up she went, pausing at every creak, listening for voices from the upper floor. The second story was quieter, the air tinged with dust and the faint scent of copier toner. She tiptoed toward the executive suite, her destination clear in her mind.

She paused at the heavy oak door, listening. No one inside. With a deep breath, she slipped through, closing it softly behind her. The package was still where she’d hidden it weeks ago, behind a row of outdated binders. Success. Now, all she had to do was make it out again, unseen. The real challenge was just beginning.

The lower offices were sufficiently warren-like that she could sneak upstairs without being observed. Years of neglected floor plans had left the basement a maze of corridors, half-lit and cluttered with abandoned filing cabinets. She kept her head down, moving with practiced ease, careful not to brush against the walls or jostle a loose stack of papers.

At the stairwell, she paused, suppressing a nervous breath. Upstairs, the late shift would be finishing their rounds, but she trusted her timing. One careful step after another, she climbed, the concrete steps echoing faintly. At the top, she pressed herself against the wall, waiting for the sound of footsteps to fade. The door to the records room was ajar—just as she’d hoped.

Inside, the air was thick with dust and secrets. She found the file she’d come for, slipped it into her bag, and retraced her path with equal caution. No alarms sounded, no voices called. Out in the cool night air, she let herself smile. Sometimes, the best way to hide was in plain sight—if you knew the warren’s ways.

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: Despite my toxic marriage, I was privileged.

responses.text:
Despite my toxic marriage, I was privileged. I knew it every time I closed the heavy front door behind me, locking out the chaos for a few precious moments. My career afforded me the freedom to travel, and my parents' support meant I never worried about making rent. To outsiders, I was the woman who had it all: a beautiful home, a successful husband, dinner parties with laughter that echoed down the hallways. But inside, the rooms were cold, and the laughter was brittle.

Still, I counted my blessings. I had a sister who called every Thursday, a rescue dog who curled at my feet, and a savings account that grew quietly with each paycheck. These were the things that sustained me, the threads of light in my shadowed world. One afternoon, after a particularly cruel argument, I sat in the garden and watched a butterfly land on my hand. It felt like a sign—a reminder that privilege, while real, didn’t protect me from pain, but it gave me choices. That day, I made one. I called my sister. I said, “I’m ready.” And for the first time, the door I closed behind me led somewhere new.

Despite my toxic marriage, I was privileged. I recognized it each time I scrolled through social media, seeing stories of women with nowhere to go and no money of their own. I had a steady job, a circle of loyal friends, and a family that would catch me if I ever fell. But still, every morning, I woke to the same bitter arguments, the silent treatments, and the constant feeling that I was shrinking inside my own home.

My privilege was a double-edged sword. It made me feel guilty for wanting more. If I was lucky compared to so many, wasn’t it selfish to crave happiness? Yet, one autumn evening, after an especially venomous fight, I found myself walking to the park, phone in hand. I called my best friend and, for the first time, told her everything. She listened, didn’t judge, and said, “You deserve peace.”

That conversation was the first step. My privilege didn’t erase my pain, but it gave me a way out. I started therapy, made plans, and slowly, began to imagine a life where I could breathe again.

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: Despite my toxic marriage, I was privileged.

responses.text:
Despite my toxic marriage, I was privileged. My job paid enough to keep a roof over my head, and my friends never let me forget my worth, even when my husband tried to convince me otherwise. I wore designer clothes to hide the bruises in my heart, and smiled at charity galas while my world quietly crumbled. I hosted perfect dinner parties, set immaculate tables, and greeted guests with practiced warmth. They envied my life, but none saw the cracks beneath the polished surface.

It was on a rainy Tuesday that I realized what privilege truly meant. I could leave. I had a passport, a savings account, and family willing to help. When I finally packed my things, I did so with trembling hands and a heart racing with both fear and hope. Not everyone trapped in a toxic marriage has options; I did. As I closed the door behind me, I whispered a silent thank you—not for the marriage, but for the privilege that would help me find myself again.

Despite my toxic marriage, I was privileged. I came from a loving family, had a good education, and worked a job that paid well. The world outside saw my life as enviable—a charming husband, elegant home, and vacations in places most people only dreamt of. But behind the carefully curated photos, my reality was far less idyllic.

Still, I recognized my advantages. I had resources and support to lean on, even if I was afraid to reach out. When the arguments became too much, I’d escape into books or long walks in the park, reminders that my world was wider than the four walls closing in on me. It took time, and courage I didn’t know I had, but one day I called my sister and confessed it all. She held my hand through the unraveling, and with every step, I was grateful—not for the pain, but for the privilege that ultimately gave me the strength to walk away.

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: Despite my toxic marriage, I was privileged.

responses.text: Despite my toxic marriage, I was privileged. My mornings began with the aroma of fresh coffee and the soft patter of rain on the kitchen window. While my husband’s words sometimes stung like nettles, I was never without a safe space, a secret haven where I could breathe and be myself. I painted my pain in brilliant colors, each brushstroke a silent rebellion. Friends would marvel at my work at gallery showings, never knowing the truth behind the beauty. My privilege was the freedom to express, to heal in ways others could not. In time, my paintings told my story for me. One collector, herself a survivor, saw beyond the colors. She reached out, offering not just admiration but understanding. That connection became my lifeline. Privilege, I realized, was not immunity from suffering, but the quiet hope that within sorrow, I could find—if not immediate escape—a path to my own liberation.

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: Liza thought this a good moment to repeat her claim: ‘These families will not be broken up.’ Kasim shrugged.

responses.text:
Liza thought this a good moment to repeat her claim: “These families will not be broken up.” Kasim shrugged. 

The late afternoon sun cast a golden haze through the dusty windows of the community center. Liza’s voice, though gentle, resonated in the silence that followed. She looked around the small circle, meeting the eyes of tired mothers and anxious fathers. 

Kasim stood by the door, arms folded. “You can’t promise that,” he said, not unkindly, but with the weight of experience. “The city council—”

“I know what the city council wants,” Liza interrupted, “but I know what these families need.”

A child, no older than six, clung to her mother’s coat. Liza knelt beside them. “No matter what happens, we’ll fight.”

Kasim’s gaze softened. He remembered when his own family had faced threats like this. “Words are one thing, Liza. Plans are another.”

She nodded. “Then let’s make a plan.”

In the fading light, hope flickered. It was small, but it was enough for tonight.

Liza thought this a good moment to repeat her claim: “These families will not be broken up.” Kasim shrugged.

He leaned against the peeling wall, picking absently at the hem of his jacket. “You say that every week,” he muttered. “But they don’t listen.”

Liza’s jaw set. “Someone has to. If we aren’t loud enough, they’ll do what they want, and we’ll wake up to empty apartments.”

The hum of children’s voices from the hallway grew louder. Kasim glanced that way, then back at Liza. “You think words will stop them?”

“Words, and action.” She looked him square in the eye. “We have lawyers. The petitions are growing. The press is interested. I’ve seen people change their minds before.”

A long silence. Kasim finally sighed. “Hope can be dangerous.”

Liza smiled, her resolve unshaken. “So can giving up.”

Outside, a child’s laughter rang out. For a moment, it sounded like a promise.

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: Liza thought this a good moment to repeat her claim: ‘These families will not be broken up.’ Kasim shrugged.

responses.text:
Liza thought this a good moment to repeat her claim: “These families will not be broken up.” Kasim shrugged.

Rain tapped softly against the metal roof as the two organizers faced each other. The room was filled with the quiet rustle of anxious movements: mothers clutching children, elders whispering prayers.

“They’ll do what they want, Liza,” Kasim said, voice low. “You know the officials. They don’t listen to us.”

Liza squared her shoulders, determination flickering in her eyes. “They will. If we stand together, they have to. That’s what community means.”

Kasim glanced at the faces around them. He saw fear, yes, but also a glimmer of hope. Maybe Liza was right. Maybe this time, their voices would be heard.

He exhaled, long and slow. “Alright. What’s the plan?”

Liza smiled, just a little. “We start tonight. We call the press, invite the council, show them the families who refuse to be separated.”

The people in the room straightened, some leaning forward. In the uncertain hush, unity began to grow.

Liza thought this a good moment to repeat her claim: “These families will not be broken up.” Kasim shrugged.

He glanced out the window, where the buses waited, engines humming. The neighborhood had always been fragile, but now the threat felt palpable.

“Promises don’t stop bulldozers, Liza,” he said quietly. “They only buy us time.”

Liza stepped closer, her voice unwavering. “Time is what we need. Time to organize, to show them we are more than names on an eviction notice. We’re neighbors. We’re a family.”

Kasim’s lips twitched in the faintest of smiles. “You always did have a way with words.”

Behind them, children played in the corridor, unaware of the gravity in the adults’ voices. Liza listened to their laughter and drew strength from it.

“That’s why I won’t give up,” she said. “Not until every last family is safe.”

For the first time that day, Kasim met her gaze and nodded. “Then neither will I.”

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: Liza thought this a good moment to repeat her claim: ‘These families will not be broken up.’ Kasim shrugged.

responses.text:
Liza thought this a good moment to repeat her claim: “These families will not be broken up.” Kasim shrugged.

From the back of the dusty hall, a radio crackled to life, leaking out a static-laced folk song. The air was thick with the scent of cumin and nervous sweat. “You make it sound easy,” Kasim replied, tracing invisible patterns on the tabletop. “But the lists are already drawn. The trucks will be here by morning.”

Liza bent to tie a child’s shoelace, her words steady. “Lists can be lost. Trucks can be delayed. We still have tonight.”

Kasim watched her, admiration flickering in his eyes despite himself. “What do you propose?”

She straightened, a plan already forming. “We scatter. Every family finds a neighbor, blends in. If we can’t be counted, we can’t be separated.”

A hush fell as her idea seeped into the crowd. Hope, fragile as a soap bubble, hovered between them. Kasim finally smiled—a quick, rare thing. “Alright, Liza. Tonight, we vanish.”

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: Liza thought this a good moment to repeat her claim: ‘These families will not be broken up.’ Kasim shrugged.

responses.text:
Liza thought this a good moment to repeat her claim: ‘These families will not be broken up.’ Kasim shrugged. He glanced at the worn floorboards, then back at her, his face unreadable. The room, once an assembly hall, echoed with whispers from the corridors outside. Liza stood taller, refusing to let doubt seep in. 

“We’ve done all we can,” Kasim said quietly. “The council’s decision is final.”

“Not if we stand together,” Liza insisted, her voice steadier than she felt. She looked around at the others—nervous mothers, anxious fathers, children clutching faded toys. Their eyes met hers with flickers of hope.

Kasim sighed, his resistance faltering. “You know what you’re asking?”

“I do. I’m asking for courage. For decency.”

A silence settled between them, thick as the dusk outside. Then, slowly, Kasim nodded. “Alright. We’ll try your way.”

Relief flooded Liza’s chest. Outside, the councilors’ footsteps approached, but she stood firm. Today, families would remain whole. And if tomorrow brought new threats, she would face them too—one promise at a time.

Liza thought this a good moment to repeat her claim: ‘These families will not be broken up.’ Kasim shrugged. He leaned back against the peeling wall, his arms folded, watching her with a skeptical expression. 

“Promises are easy, Liza,” he said. “You know how things work here. Orders come from above.”

She nodded, but her jaw set with determination. The room was cramped, filled with anxious faces—mothers gripping children, fathers pacing. News of the separation had sent fear through every heart. Liza would not let that fear win.

“Then we change how things work,” she replied quietly. “We stand together. We refuse.”

Kasim’s eyes flickered. For a moment, she thought he might argue. But instead, he sighed, a sound heavy with resignation and hope.

“All right,” he said. “But if this goes wrong—”

She interrupted, “If it goes wrong, we fight harder. We owe them that.”

Outside, the guards’ footsteps echoed closer. Liza straightened her shoulders, feeling the weight of every gaze in the room. She would keep her promise, whatever it cost.

Liza thought this a good moment to repeat her claim: ‘These families will not be broken up.’ Kasim shrugged. He had heard her say it before, but this time there was more conviction in her voice. Liza thought this a good moment to repeat her claim: ‘These families will not be broken up.’ Kasim shrugged. He looked tired, the lines on his face deeper than usual.

“You keep saying that,” he replied, voice soft, almost apologetic. “But they have the power, not us.”

Liza shook her head. “We have each other. That counts for more than you think.”

A small child tugged at her sleeve, eyes wide. Liza knelt, offering a gentle smile. “We’re not going anywhere without you, sweetheart.”

Kasim watched her, something shifting in his gaze. He remembered when hope used to feel possible. Maybe it still was, if only because Liza refused to surrender it.

As the guards approached, Liza stood, linking arms with the families. Kasim hesitated only a moment before joining them. Together, they formed an unbroken chain, daring the world to try and separate them.

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: Liza thought this a good moment to repeat her claim: ‘These families will not be broken up.’ Kasim shrugged.

responses.text:
Liza thought this a good moment to repeat her claim: ‘These families will not be broken up.’ Kasim shrugged. He pulled his scarf tighter around his neck, the cold seeping in through cracks in the old schoolhouse windows. "You say it like you can change the weather," he said quietly, nodding toward the snow swirling outside. 

But Liza shook her head, determination sharpening her features. "You can’t stop the wind, but you can build a wall against it. That’s what we’re doing here. We are the wall."

Kasim let out a slow breath, watching it fog in the air. Around them, children huddled in blankets, mothers spooned out thin soup. The distant rumble of engines—government vans—grew louder by the minute.

"Walls fall," Kasim said, but his tone held a question, not a challenge.

"Not this one," Liza replied. She strode to the door, threw it open, and stood tall in the threshold, the storm swirling around her. Behind her, the families rose as one, silent and steadfast. 

Kasim followed, heart pounding, as the first van pulled into view. Maybe, just maybe, hope could hold against the storm.

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: He recanted his confession less than twenty-four hours later, saying it was coerced.

responses.text:
He recanted his confession less than twenty-four hours later, saying it was coerced. The detectives exchanged glances across the interrogation table, their faces unreadable. Julian’s voice trembled as he recounted the marathon questioning, the relentless questions, the bright light that never dimmed, and the promises whispered at sunrise. He swore that he hadn’t been at the scene, that he’d only said what they wanted to hear after they threatened to call his employer and ruin his life. 

His attorney sat beside him, notepad in hand, eyes narrowed in concentration. She pressed for details, gently encouraging him to remember every word, every threat, every moment of doubt that had made him sign the statement. Julian’s mind raced—he replayed the fear, the exhaustion, the moment his resolve broke. He wondered if anyone would believe him now, if the truth could outweigh the written confession. As he finished, his lawyer squeezed his shoulder reassuringly. “We’ll fight this,” she promised. “The truth has a way of coming out.”

Outside, rain battered the windows, as if the world itself was impatient for justice. Julian stared at the door, hopeful and afraid, waiting for his second chance to begin.

He recanted his confession less than twenty-four hours later, saying it was coerced. The small, fluorescent-lit interview room seemed to close in around him as he stared at his trembling hands. Detective Monroe slid a cup of cold coffee across the table, her eyes narrowed. "You expect us to believe that?" she asked, voice flat.

He nodded, voice barely above a whisper. "I was scared. You kept me here for hours and wouldn’t let me call anyone. You said if I didn’t confess, things would get worse. I just wanted it to stop."

Monroe sighed, jotting something in her notebook. Outside, the lawyer he’d finally been allowed to see paced anxiously. The truth was stubborn, refusing to fit neatly into anyone’s narrative. Evidence had surfaced—a bus ticket stub, a security camera glitch—casting doubt on the original story. 

As the hours stretched on, the lines between guilt and innocence blurred. But he clung to the hope that someone, somewhere, would listen. For now, he waited, watching the rain streak the window, praying his real story would finally be heard.

responses.text:

“I didn’t do it,” he whispered, voice raw from sleeplessness. “But they wouldn’t let me leave. They said if I didn’t sign, no one would believe me anyway.”

His lawyer listened, tapping a pen thoughtfully. She’d heard stories like this before. They would fight to get the interrogation tapes, to expose the tactics used. But she knew the road ahead would be long, uphill, and unforgiving. Outside, the first rays of morning light crept through the blinds, offering a glimmer of hope that the truth might still have a chance.

He recanted his confession less than twenty-four hours later, saying it was coerced. The news barely made a ripple at first, but then questions began to surface. People who knew him—friends, neighbors, his old high school teacher—couldn’t reconcile the quiet, thoughtful man they remembered with the confession splashed across the morning papers.

His lawyer filed a motion for a new hearing, citing the long hours and the aggressive tactics used during questioning. In court, his voice was steady. “I said what they wanted to hear because I was scared. But I didn’t do it.” The judge listened, stone-faced, while the prosecutor frowned at the new turn of events.

Outside the courthouse, reporters gathered, hungry for the next twist. But for him, it wasn’t about headlines. It was about clearing his name and reclaiming his life, one painstaking step at a time. As the day faded, hope flickered quietly, fragile but determined.

He stood, hands shaking, and spoke into the microphone, voice cracking. "I was afraid. They told me I’d never see my family again. I didn’t know what else to do."

His mother’s eyes filled with tears in the front row. The prosecutor scowled, flipping through a stack of evidence. The judge pressed her lips together, as if weighing the gravity of a human soul. Outside, protestors gathered, their signs demanding justice—for the victim, for the accused, for the truth.

As the hearing adjourned, the world seemed to hang in suspension. Was he a criminal or a victim? A liar or a survivor? Only time—and the investigation yet to come—would tell. But as he was led back to his cell, he felt a small ember of hope that the truth might finally ignite.

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: I once met a Manx man whose daughter had taken her own life after a year and a day spent in some horrific faerie kingdom so lovely that its beauty

responses.text:
I once met a Manx man whose daughter had taken her own life after a year and a day spent in some horrific faerie kingdom so lovely that its beauty haunted her waking hours. He told me his tale on the rocky cliffs of Maughold, the sea lashing grey below us. His daughter, Meara, had vanished one misted Beltane night, drawn by strange music drifting from the glen. When she returned, her eyes sparkled with a strange light, and her laughter was threaded with sorrow.

She spoke of crystal rivers and silver-leaved trees, of feasts that never ended and dances that left her feet bleeding. Yet, behind every delight, she sensed an ancient malice, as if the beauty was a mask for something cold and pitiless. She could not bear the dullness of mortal life, he said, nor the memory of eyes that watched her in the twilight. In the end, she chose silence over longing, and her father, standing on the wind-scoured headland, watched the gulls wheel, still listening for her laughter on the wind.

I once met a Manx man whose daughter had taken her own life after a year and a day spent in some horrific faerie kingdom so lovely that its beauty twisted her heart. He told me the story in a low voice, his eyes fixed on the restless sea. She had vanished at the edge of the woods, and when she returned, she seemed changed, her gaze distant, her smile brittle. She described moonlit dances on velvet moss, feasts that never ended, and music that made her soul ache.

But she also spoke of shadows moving behind the trees, and voices whispering secrets that no human should hear. The faeries' world, he said, was a trap—a place where longing and terror were woven together so tightly you could not pull them apart. She could not bear to live in the world she had known, nor could she return to the world she had left. In the end, the memory of such terrible beauty was too much for her heart to hold.

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: Oh, I’m great.

responses.text:
Oh, I’m great. That’s what I told everyone, anyway. I flashed a smile, laughed at the right times, and kept my head high. But as I walked home through the crowded streets, the weight of the day caught up with me. The truth was, I wasn’t sure how I felt anymore. Maybe I was just tired, or maybe I was overwhelmed by all the little things piling up, like unopened letters on my kitchen table.

As I unlocked my door, my cat greeted me with a purr and a head butt against my leg. I sat on the floor, letting her settle into my lap. For a moment, it was just the two of us, and the world felt a little quieter. I took a deep breath, stroking her soft fur, realizing that maybe it was okay not to be completely honest with everyone else—as long as I could be honest with myself. "Tomorrow," I whispered, "I'll try again."

And with that, I let myself just be, if only for the night.

Oh, I’m great. That’s what I said, and for the first time in months, I actually meant it. The sun was shining, birds were singing, and the smell of fresh coffee filled my kitchen. I’d worked late into the night, perfecting every stroke, second-guessing every color. But as I looked at my collection now, I felt something new: pride. Not the nervous, hopeful pride of a dreamer, but the steady confidence of someone who knows they’re ready.

I packed my canvases carefully, grabbed my favorite lucky pen, and headed out the door. As I walked down the street, I couldn’t help but smile at every stranger I met. Today, I was great. And maybe, just maybe, the world would see it too.

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: He recanted his confession less than twenty-four hours later, saying it was coerced.

responses.text: He recanted his confession less than twenty-four hours later, saying it was coerced. As dawn broke through the slatted blinds of the interrogation room, Marcus’s voice was hoarse but resolute. “I didn’t do it. They wouldn’t let me call my lawyer. They threatened me.” The detective, who had seemed so certain the previous night, now frowned, flipping through the thin file that was supposed to hold the truth. Outside, Marcus’s sister paced the corridor, clutching her phone, whispering desperate prayers. The small town had already begun to gossip, and Marcus’s name was on everyone’s lips. But as the day wore on, a new witness came forward—a neighbor who’d seen something that didn’t fit the narrative. By sunset, the case that seemed open-and-shut unraveled, threads of doubt weaving through the community. Marcus sat quietly, hope flickering in his eyes, as the truth edged closer to the surface. Sometimes, he thought, the hardest thing is convincing people you’re innocent after they’ve heard you say you’re guilty.

He recanted his confession less than twenty-four hours later, saying it was coerced. The words lingered in the cramped office, echoing off the peeling paint and dusty blinds. Detective Sandoval stared at the statement, his jaw tightening. It wasn’t the first time he’d seen someone take back their words, but this case was different. The evidence was flimsy, the motive thin, and now, with this new claim, the whole investigation teetered on the edge of collapse.

Across town, Maya sat at her kitchen table, scrolling through the news updates with shaking hands. She knew Marcus—he wasn’t capable of what they accused him of. The confession had felt wrong from the beginning. Now, with his recantation, hope bloomed cautiously in her chest.

As the legal teams scrambled and the press swarmed, Marcus’s voice—quiet but determined—kept repeating the truth. He wanted to be heard, not just by the police, but by everyone who had so quickly judged him. And in that moment, Maya realized that sometimes the most important stories are the ones we almost never believe.

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: Liza thought this a good moment to repeat her claim: ‘These families will not be broken up.’ Kasim shrugged.

responses.text:
Liza thought this a good moment to repeat her claim: ‘These families will not be broken up.’ Kasim shrugged. He leaned back in his chair, the legs creaking under his weight.

‘You can’t promise that, Liza. Not with the new orders.’

But Liza stood her ground, hands pressed flat on the table. The room was quiet except for the rain tapping the windows. She looked at the stacks of files—each one a family, each one a story tangled with hope and fear.

‘We’re not machines, Kasim. We don’t have to follow every order without thinking. We can make room. We can find a way.’

Kasim sighed, rubbing his eyes. ‘If they find out, it’s both our jobs. Maybe worse.’

Liza shook her head. ‘If we don’t try, who will?’

He looked at her, searching her face for uncertainty, but found only resolve. For a moment, the room felt lighter, as if her determination was enough to hold everything together. Kasim nodded, almost imperceptibly. Maybe, just maybe, she was right.

Liza thought this a good moment to repeat her claim: ‘These families will not be broken up.’ Kasim shrugged. He shuffled the pages on the table, avoiding her gaze.

‘It’s not up to us anymore, Liza. They make the rules, not you.’

But Liza’s jaw tightened. ‘We have a say, Kasim. We’re their only chance.’

A tense silence settled between them. Liza glanced at the small photo pinned to the notice board—a family of four, arms wrapped around each other, eyes bright but uncertain. She remembered their voices, their promises to each other. She couldn’t let bureaucracy tear them apart.

‘If we don’t fight for them, who will?’ she whispered.

Kasim finally met her gaze, something softening in his expression. ‘You always say that, but you know it’s not simple.’

Liza smiled, just a little. ‘Nothing worth doing ever is.’

Outside, the sound of laughter drifted in from the yard, mingling with the hope that maybe, just maybe, she could keep her promise.

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: Liza thought this a good moment to repeat her claim: ‘These families will not be broken up.’ Kasim shrugged.

responses.text:
Liza thought this a good moment to repeat her claim: ‘These families will not be broken up.’ Kasim shrugged. He had heard her say this many times over the past few weeks, but the uncertainty in the air was thicker than ever.

‘How can you be so sure?’ he asked, voice barely above a whisper. ‘You know what the council decided.’

Liza drew in a slow breath. The children’s laughter echoed from the next room, a bittersweet melody. ‘Because I made them a promise. I won’t let bureaucracy undo it. I’ll talk to the council again. There’s still room to negotiate.’

Kasim shook his head, not in disagreement, but in resignation. ‘You’re braver than me, Liza. I just don’t want to give them false hope.’

She offered a weary smile. ‘Hope is all we have right now. If we stop fighting for them, who will?’

Kasim glanced at the doorway where a small face peeked in, eyes wide with worry. He nodded, a silent pact forming between them. For now, they would fight together.

Liza thought this a good moment to repeat her claim: ‘These families will not be broken up.’ Kasim shrugged. He glanced at the stack of forms beside him, their edges curling from too many nervous hands.

‘You can’t protect everyone, Liza,’ he replied, his tone weary but not unkind. ‘They want fast answers. Fast solutions. We don’t get to choose.’

Liza’s fingers tightened around her mug. ‘We can slow things down. We can ask for more time. I won’t just stand by and let them be separated.’

Kasim studied her, the determination etched in her brow. He remembered when he’d felt that fire too, before the long nights and endless meetings dulled it.

‘All right,’ he said finally. ‘We’ll do what we can. But you know it’s a fight.’

Liza’s eyes flashed. ‘Then we’ll fight. Together.’

For the first time in days, Kasim managed a faint smile. Maybe together, they had a chance after all.

She refused to let the chill in his voice reach her. ‘People care. We care. That’s enough for now.’

Kasim turned, the faintest smile on his lips. ‘You always believe in people.’

‘Someone has to. If we forget what we’re fighting for, then we’ve already lost.’

A distant bell echoed from the harbor. The children, unaware, played in the courtyard below. Liza pressed her hand to the glass, as if shielding them from what might come. She glanced at Kasim, her resolve unshaken.

‘Let’s find another way. One they haven’t thought of yet.’

Kasim’s eyes softened. ‘You’re trouble, Liza.’

She grinned. ‘Only the good kind.’

If we’re not in the same room, then I’m usually working on his book. It’s a strange collaboration; I write the words he could never say, filling the pages with his ideas, my voice. He trusts me with his secrets, his stories, even though we rarely speak face to face. Sometimes I hear his voice in my head, dictating a character’s line or offering a gentle correction. Other times, I imagine him in the next room, hunched over his notes, smiling at a sentence I’ve crafted. 

We meet only once a week, exchanging pages, feedback, and coffee. The rest of the time, he sends me cryptic emails—snippets of dialogue, fragments of dreams. I piece them together, weaving his world into something tangible. The book is almost finished now, and with each chapter, I feel us drawing closer, two voices merging into one. I wonder what will happen when we finally sit down together, side by side, the story complete. Will we have anything left to say? Or will we realize that, in creating his book, we’ve written our own?

If we’re not in the same room, then I’m usually working on his book. He trusts me to edit his drafts, to polish his prose and fix his wayward punctuation. Sometimes, it’s easier to understand him through the chapters he sends than in our brief conversations over coffee. Each page is a puzzle, a glimpse into his mind—his childhood memories, his quiet humor, his fears he never voices aloud.

Tonight, as rain taps the window, I’m lost in Chapter Seven. There’s a new character, a woman who always leaves the room before the conversation ends. I wonder if she’s based on someone, or if she’s just a shadow of his loneliness. I tap out a message: “Who is she?” But I know he won’t reply right away. That’s how we work—apart, but never disconnected. The story flows between us, a silent conversation we’re both too shy to have aloud. I fix a typo, smile at a clever metaphor. Maybe someday, when the book is done, we’ll find ourselves in the same room and realize we’ve been writing our own story all along.

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: If we’re not in the same room, then I’m usually working on his book.

responses.text:
If we’re not in the same room, then I’m usually working on his book. It started as a simple favor—typing up handwritten notes, correcting grammar, shaping paragraphs—but it’s grown into something else. Sometimes I feel like I know his protagonist better than I know him. I can sense where the story’s headed before he tells me, anticipate the cadence of his sentences, the turns his mind might take. 

He trusts me with his words, and I trust that every chapter I polish brings us closer, even when we’re apart. The clatter of my keyboard fills the silence, punctuated by the occasional ping of a message: "How does this scene feel?" or "Too melodramatic?" Those messages tie us together, an invisible thread running through laptops and living rooms. 

Tonight, as rain taps on the window and the cursor blinks on another unfinished page, I realize I’m not just working on his book—I’m shaping our story, one page at a time.

If we’re not in the same room, then I’m usually working on his book. It’s become my way of keeping him close, even when he’s off at readings, book signings, or just out for a walk, chasing inspiration. I sit at my desk, headphones on, and sift through his rough drafts. Sometimes his voice echoes in my mind, laughing at his own jokes or grumbling about a stubborn plot point.

I change a word here, rearrange a sentence there, always careful to keep his style intact. It’s a delicate dance: making the story better without making it mine. But in these quiet hours, I feel like a part of his world, trusted with the raw pieces of his imagination.

When he returns, he always asks what I think of the latest chapter. We talk, sometimes argue, always laugh. And when he leaves again, I return to the manuscript, still working—still connected. As long as there’s another page to edit, we’re never really apart.

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: Liza thought this a good moment to repeat her claim: ‘These families will not be broken up.’ Kasim shrugged.

responses.text:
Liza thought this a good moment to repeat her claim: “These families will not be broken up.” Kasim shrugged. He stood by the window, arms folded, watching the dusk settle over the camp. Beyond the chain-link fence, children’s laughter rose and fell, a hopeful sound in a place built from uncertainty.

“It’s not up to us,” he said quietly. “You know that.”

Liza pressed on. “It should be. Someone has to stand up. If we let them go through with it, what are we here for?”

Kasim’s eyes flickered to hers, a rare softness breaking his usually guarded gaze. “You’re brave, Liza. But bravery doesn’t change orders.”

She shook her head. “Then we change the orders. Or we make them impossible to carry out.”

A silence hung, thick with the stakes neither wanted to voice. Finally, Kasim’s resolve faltered. “What do you have in mind?”

Liza smiled, relief and determination mingling. “I’ll need your help. And a list of the families scheduled for transfer. We have until morning.”

The last light slanted through the window. Outside, hope flickered. Inside, resolve hardened into action.

Liza thought this a good moment to repeat her claim: “These families will not be broken up.” Kasim shrugged. He had heard it before, many times, in many meetings. This time, though, her voice was steadier, the determination unmistakable.

“Liza, we can’t promise that,” he said, though not unkindly. “You know the orders come from above.”

She clenched her jaw. “Orders or not, there are ways. We can make sure that the paperwork gets lost, or that names are misspelled. Small mistakes, delays—enough to keep them together, at least for a while.”

Kasim looked at her, his expression unreadable. “And when they ask questions?”

“Then we answer. Or we don’t. I’m done watching children pulled from their parents in the name of efficiency.”

He sighed, then gave a reluctant nod. “You’ll need help.”

Liza managed a thin smile. “I know.”

Outside, a child’s laugh echoed down the hallway. Liza straightened her shoulders. The night shift would begin soon, and with it, the quiet work of defiance.

Liza thought this a good moment to repeat her claim: “These families will not be broken up.” Kasim shrugged. He crossed the small room, his footsteps echoing softly against the linoleum. “You’ve said that before,” he replied, his voice low, not unkind but weary. 

“They’re counting on us,” Liza insisted, her hands gripping the folder she’d brought. Inside were names, histories, photographs – proof of lives intertwined. “We can’t let them down, Kasim. If we stand firm, maybe they’ll reconsider.”

Kasim looked at her for a long moment, then at the folder, then away. “They don’t listen to people like us.”

“Then we make them listen,” Liza said, determination sharpening her tone. “We document everything. We show the world what happens here.”

Kasim hesitated, but something in Liza’s urgency pulled him closer. “All right. But if we do this, we do it together.”

She nodded, relief mingling with resolve. Outside, the muffled sounds of children playing filtered through the window, a reminder of what was at stake.

Liza thought this a good moment to repeat her claim: “These families will not be broken up.” Kasim shrugged. He reached for his mug, swirling the cold tea inside, eyes distant. “You’re too optimistic,” he said, not unkindly.

Liza straightened. “No, I’m stubborn. There’s a difference.”

Kasim almost smiled. “The paperwork is already in motion. What can you really do?”

“We can stall. Appeal. Make noise so it’s harder for them to ignore us.” She leaned forward, voice fierce. “If we give up, they’ll be separated by next week.”

He considered her words, the lines of worry on her face. “And if we get in trouble?”

Liza’s answer was immediate. “Then it’s worth it. I won’t be complicit.”

Kasim looked away, but she saw the hint of agreement in his expression. “Fine. Tell me what you need me to do.”

The resolve in Liza’s eyes was unshakeable. This time, she would not let go.

I roll my eyes, hit play, and settle in beside her. We always fight over who gets the last slice of pizza, but we never argue about what to watch. As the opening credits roll, I realize these small rituals are what really make a place feel like home.

“I’m gonna change in the bathroom; you get the episode pulled up.” I find the remote, connect to the right app, and get it ready to play. The familiar logo flashes on the screen, and I scroll down to our favorite season. The bathroom door clicks shut behind her, and I hear the muffled swish of clothing as she changes. I take a moment to glance around the living room, noticing a pair of socks stuffed behind a cushion and the lingering scent of popcorn from last night.

When she returns, hair tied up and wearing her favorite oversized hoodie, she flops down next to me. “Ready?” she asks with a grin. I nod and hit play. As the theme song fills the room, we settle in, our laughter mingling with the dialogue on the screen. Outside, rain taps at the windows, but inside, we’re wrapped up in a world of our own, content to spend another night together, episode after episode.

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: This apparently meant she was mature enough (“sexually active,” they said) at twelve that anyone could have killed her, not just the bus driver who had the nude photos.

responses.text:
This apparently meant she was mature enough (“sexually active,” they said) at twelve that anyone could have killed her, not just the bus driver who had the nude photos. Her mother sat on the stiff chair in the police station, hands shaking as she stared at her daughter’s untouched backpack. The detective, voice low and tired, explained how the law saw girls like Ana—how the world always found ways to place blame on the most vulnerable. 

Outside, rain tapped against the windows, blurring the neon lights. Ana had just wanted to ride the bus home after choir practice. The bus driver, Mr. Lyle, had always been nice. She never knew about the photos until the day she disappeared. Now the city whispered, each rumor harsher than the last, as if they were trying to erase Ana’s laughter from the world. 

Her mother clutched a frayed photo, refusing to let anyone call her daughter anything but a child. But the system was already moving on, case files stacked and names replaced. Still, she waited every evening at the bus stop, hoping Ana would step off, safe, as if nothing had ever happened.

This apparently meant she was mature enough (“sexually active,” they said) at twelve that anyone could have killed her, not just the bus driver who had the nude photos. The words echoed in the courtroom, bouncing off the walls and landing heavily in the lap of her mother, who could not comprehend how such logic had a place in justice. They said the evidence was circumstantial, the bus driver’s guilt uncertain, and the world seemed to shrink to a point where reason no longer mattered.

Outside, the town gossiped in whispers, their eyes hard and eager. The stories grew, folding in on themselves, until the facts were buried beneath layers of shame and suspicion. Her friends left flowers at the edge of the woods, where her bicycle was found. Some said she was wild, others that she was just unlucky. But her mother remembered a girl who braided her dolls’ hair, who cried at movies and still slept with the light on.

In the end, the law decided no one was to blame. The bus route resumed. The photos were sealed away. And the silence of justice was louder than any verdict.

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: This apparently meant she was mature enough (“sexually active,” they said) at twelve that anyone could have killed her, not just the bus driver who had the nude photos.

This apparently meant she was mature enough (“sexually active,” they said) at twelve that anyone could have killed her, not just the bus driver who had the nude photos. The jury listened, stoic, as if the loss of a child was a matter for paperwork and procedure. The defense argued that C.D. wandered, that she was precocious, that men were tempted. Her mother’s hands shook in her lap, clutching a ribbon that once tied back her daughter’s hair. When the verdict came, it barely mattered anymore. The city moved on, the bus route replaced, the driver a shadow in the periphery of memory. But her mother refused to forget—she carried her daughter’s laughter like a secret, waiting for the world to remember that C.D. was only twelve.

This apparently meant she was mature enough (“sexually active,” they said) at twelve that anyone could have killed her, not just the bus driver who had the nude photos. The officers explained this to her grandmother in hushed tones, as if speaking more softly would soften the cruelty. The file was closed, the headlines faded, but the pain remained, etched into every corner of the apartment above the bakery where she used to help knead dough on Saturday mornings.

Neighbors stopped asking questions. The family learned to avoid the old bus stop, the one with the peeling paint and the missing persons poster, now sun-bleached and curling at the edges. Life continued in fits and starts, but there was always a weight, a sense that the world had decided her youth was a technicality, an inconvenience for legal paperwork. Her story became a cautionary tale, a whispered warning, but to her grandmother, she was still the little girl who loved lemon cookies and made wishes on dandelions. Justice, they said, had been served. But her absence was a wound that would never heal.

Her sister, Lila, watched from the doorway, clutching Marley’s favorite book. She remembered how Marley would invent stories about the heroes inside—brave girls who always found their way home. prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: She wished that she could love him in the same way that he loved her, except she didn’t know how.

responses.text:
She wished that she could love him in the same way that he loved her, except she didn’t know how. It wasn’t for lack of trying. Every morning, she’d wake up hoping the warmth of his arms would unlock something inside her, but her heart remained silent, like a bird refusing to sing. She admired his patience—the way he remembered her favorite coffee, the way he listened to her stories, even the ones she’d told before. He never seemed to tire. Sometimes, she caught herself wishing she could mirror his devotion, that she could give back the unwavering affection he offered so freely.

One evening, as autumn leaves rustled outside, he looked at her and smiled, a gentle sadness in his eyes. "You don’t have to force it," he whispered. Those words lingered in the air, settling softly between them. She realized love wasn’t always a thunderclap; sometimes it was a slow dawn. Maybe she could learn to love him, not in the way he loved her, but in her own quiet way—a love that grew slowly, tender and true, shaped by gentle patience and honest hope.

She wished that she could love him in the same way that he loved her, except she didn’t know how. Every gesture he made was filled with affection—small notes left on her pillow, dinners cooked after a long day, laughter that filled the cracks in her heart. She wanted to reciprocate, to give him the same unwavering devotion, but something always held her back, like a locked door she couldn’t find the key to.

She tried to explain, fumbling for words as they sat together on the porch swing. He squeezed her hand, his eyes soft with understanding. "Love doesn’t have to look the same," he told her gently. "Just be here with me. That’s enough."

Relief flooded her chest. Maybe it was okay that her love was quieter, uncertain, a work in progress. As they watched the sky turn pink and gold, she realized that sometimes, loving someone meant letting go of expectations—hers, his, and the world’s. She might never love him in exactly the way he loved her, but maybe, just maybe, her way would be enough.

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: She wished that she could love him in the same way that he loved her, except she didn’t know how.

responses.text:
